Subject.descriptiveTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--Pictorial Works|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention--Pictorial works|~|HIV infections--Pictorial works|~|AIDS (Disease)--Pictorial works|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control--Pictorial Works
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS Posters Collection
Summary: Digitized AIDS posters from 44 countries. Demonstrates the efforts taken by various countries to promote AIDS awareness and modify risk behaviors.  The physical collection was originally acquired by the History and Special Collections division of the Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library in 2005, and has been expanded through later acquisitions.

Publisher.publisherName: Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Caring for people with AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a painting by Australian Aboriginal artist, Bronwyn Bancroft, inside a black border with white text. Painting has a  multi-colored wavy background with two black silhouettes reaching toward each other and the image of an eye in between them.|~|Part of the "Everybody's business" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT002.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: This painting shows that people can safely care for family and friends with AIDS. The waves around the central image suggest the warmth of friendship and love that can greatly benefit the well-being of someone with AIDS. In the center is an eye looking towards the future when a cure will hopefully be found.

Subject.conceptTopic: Indigenous peoples--Australia|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|International Year of the World's Indigenous People (Program)
Publisher.publisherName: Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Australian aboriginal painting about AIDS [descriptive]
Description.note: Poster depicts an Australian aboriginal painting by artist Zane Saunders on a yellow background, with four separate views of details of that painting. It suggests that people are at the center of nature's cycle of life, and that we have a duty to protect human life by using condoms.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT003.
Description.condition: Poster text: This painting depicts the continuing cycle of life and the role all people must play to ensure an AIDS free future. Dragonflies, frogs, birds, butterfly [sic] and the two people reach out to touch the tree of life and hope and the seeds on the shield. The tree's roots turn into water, the mainstay of life.|~|Additional poster text: This poster was commissioned by the National AIDS campaign of the Commonwealth Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services in response to the 1993 International Year for the World's Indigenous Peoples which has as its theme, Indigenous People - a New Partnership.

Title: People with something in common: we are all HIV positive [inscribed]
Description.note: 10 black and white photographs of twelve individuals, primarily men, some with captions. Poster suggests that we all have things in common with people who are HIV positive, and that we shouldn't discriminate against them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT005.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Someone's boss, someone's son, someone's child, someone's workmate, someone's friend.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AID S [inscribed]
Description.note: Central image in poster is of a naked man and woman embracing while suspended in water inside a clear plastic bag. The rest of the poster consists of a photo montage including pictures of people, medical supplies, typewriter keys against a dark background. Text suggests the need to confront the reality of AIDS without fear or blame.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT006.

Name.creator: National AIDS Council (Papua New Guinea)
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: It can happen to anyone-- it can happen to you [inscribed]
Description.note: A woman sits on the floor on a mat, holding an infant in her lap. She faces a window with partially drawn curtains. The room is dark, lit only by a lantern in the corner and dim light from the window. Poster suggests the mother's moment of realization that, not only is she infected, she has also passed the virus on to her infant.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT007.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: "I never thought AIDS would affect my family. I was always faithful to my husband, but he got the virus. It was only when I gave birth that I found out I had the AIDS virus... and now my baby has it too."
Description.caption: Protect yourself from AIDS. Don't have sex, be faithful, or always use a condom

Publisher.publisherName: Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services|~|Aboriginal Health Workers of Australia (Queensland)
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: You don't have to be a queenie to get AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Cartoon depicting a married man who celebrates a "big day" by going to a bar and having unprotected sex with someone with AIDS. On returning home, he infects his wife, and they both get sick. He is shown in a hospital bed. The last frame of the cartoon is a cemetery, with four headstones spelling out the word "AIDS." The poster suggests that it is not only homosexual men who get, and pass on, the AIDS virus.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT008.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: A man has sex with someone who has AIDS. He goes back to his wife, who gets AIDS from him. They all get very, very sick. The end.
Description.caption: You can't cure AIDS, you can only be careful! Use a condom

Title: Safe sex can be fun [inscribed]
Description.note: Multicolor drawing of a couple, one with an arm around the other's shoulders, both wearing T-shirts reading "Be Safe, Be Sure" and surrounded by the text of the poster.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT011.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: If you kiss, touch, hug, pet or cuddle, you can't get AIDS. Everybody needs to know the facts about safe sex and AIDS. Everybody. And how do you find out? That's easy! Health centres, doctors, youth centres and schools have information on all the facts, and more, that you need to know. If you do have sex, always use a condom.|~|Additional poster text: We do it safely.

Nur ohne Angst ist es möglich, Menschen mit AIDS am sozialen Leben teilnehmen zu lassen. Mehr darüber im AIDS-Ratgeber für Alle. Erhältlich bei der Österreichischen AIDS-Hilfe (Spendenkonto P.S.K. 7939.600)|~|Translation of additional poster text: Having AIDS or being HIV-positive causes social isolation. People with AIDS or HIV infection need our help. AIDS cannot be caused by casual contact, even at work. Knowledge is power, takes away fear. More information available in a brochure from Österreichische AIDS-Hilfe.

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU028.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Fear

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Edith Hirsch: Bilder zum Thema AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster shows an example of the artwork of Edith Hirsch and advertises an exhibit and sale of her art held in 1988 to benefit Österreichische AIDS-Hilfe. The painting is of several images superimposed: a butterfly, a woman's open legs, and an unrolled condom. In the lower right corner is a small green inchworm. The World AIDS Day logo for 1988 appears at the bottom of the poster, and apparently it fell during the dates of the exhibit.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU046.

Publisher.publisherName: Belgium. Ministère de la communauté française|~|Plate Forme prévention SIDA
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Séduire, ce sont 1000 petits gestes plus 1 [inscribed]
Description.note: A daisy consists of a condom for a center, and its petals are labeled l'écouter, titiller, beaucoup rire, tout goûter, les yeux bandés, désirer.  The cover of the document Permis de Séduire [License to Seduce] is also displayed.  Its design imitates a Permis de Conduire [driver's license], and it contains a condom and instructions on how to use it, as well as information on the modes of transmission of HIV.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE003.
AltTitle.translated: To seduce, there are a thousand little moves plus one
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Le sida ne se guérit pas encore.  Pensez à vous protéger.  Lors des relations sexuelles, le préservatif peut vous protéger du sida et de maladies sexuellement transmissibles.  De l'info et un préservatif gratuit demandez votre Permis de Séduire. [AIDS is not cured yet. Think about protecting yourself. During sexual intercourse, the condom can protect you from AIDS and sexually-transmitted diseases. For information and a free condom, ask for your "License to Seduce."]

Name.creator: Agence de prévention du Sida
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Belgian AIDS poster presenting the means by which the virus is not transmitted in the workplace [descriptive]
Description.note: Objects commonly found in the workplace are pictured with captions explaining that they are not means for transmission of the AIDS virus: Coffee mug, ashtray, bar of soap, postage stamps, telephone receiver, scissors, awl, screwdriver, pencil, toilet seat, compass, razor knife, first aid kit, bottled water, french fries, a fork in a piece of pie, a pair of partially-full wine glasses, and a hand shake.  Also depicted is a condom in a foil packet.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE008.
Description.condition: Poster text: A condition de ne pas melanger le sexe et le travail, il n'y a aucun risque de transmission du virus du sida dans l'entreprise.  [If you do not mix sex with work, there is no risk of transmission of the AIDS virus in the workplace]|~|Additional poster text: L'agence de prevention du Sida lutte contre l'exclusion des seropositifs.

Name.creator: International Labour Office|~|World Health Organization
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Guidelines for a joint labour-management workplace policy on AIDS (from World Health Organization and International Labour Office)
Description.note: Pink background; blue text. Column of centered text with policies; stylized images alternately at right & left margins. Images show: 3 people in a triangle; a test tube; lips with the "No" sign; human with hand over mouth; giant hand with person & "No" sign; 3 people in square with purple border; hand with wrench.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CC002.|~|Date on back of poster, 2003, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: On-site education on AIDS for all workers and management personnel should be provided. Employment or pre-employment testing for HIV antibody is unnecessary and should not be required. Like all medical information, information on whether someone is infected with HIV should be confidential. There should be no obligation for an employee to inform the employer about his or her HIV/AIDS status. HIV infection is not a reason for dismissal. Workers who are HIV infected must be protected from any discrimination or stigmatization. Since HIV infection by itself does not limit fitness to work, no changes in working arrangements are necessary. But if an employee becomes impaired by illness related to HIV, reasonable alternative work arrangements should be made to help the worker stay on the job.

Title: 在校內血液的處理
AltTitle.other: Zai xiao nei xue ye de chu li
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CC007.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Blood handling in schools
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Blood precautions in schools: To safeguard oneself against contracting blood-borne diseases including AIDS and Hepatitis B, appropriate precautionary measures should be adopted and applied generally. 1. Equip the first aid box with essential items including disposable gloves, cotton wool, gauze and antiseptic for emergency use. 2. Don’t touch blood or wounds with bare hands. 3. Wear disposable gloves when handling wounds or blood-stained materials. 4. Dress all wounds properly after cleaning. 5. If direct contact with blood or body fluids has occurred, wash promptly and thoroughly with soap and water. 6. Clean all blood-stained surfaces with household bleach. 7. Blood-soiled gloves, towels, cotton wool, dressing etc. should be put in plastic bag and sealed for disposal. 8. Handle sharp objects carefully to avoid injury, e.g. 捳椀猀猀漀爀猀Ⰰ 瀀椀渀猀Ⰰ 渀攀攀搀氀攀猀Ⰰ 最氀愀猀猀 椀渀猀琀爀甀洀攀渀琀猀⸀ 㤀⸀ 䄀瘀漀椀搀 琀栀攀 甀猀攀 漀昀 栀甀洀愀渀 戀氀漀漀搀 漀爀 挀攀氀氀 猀愀洀瀀氀攀猀 椀渀 氀愀戀漀爀愀琀漀爀礀 攀砀瀀攀爀椀洀攀渀琀猀⸀ ㄀　⸀ 匀攀攀欀 洀攀搀椀挀愀氀 愀搀瘀椀挀攀 椀渀 挀愀猀攀 漀昀 搀漀甀戀琀⸀ 倀甀瀀椀氀猀 猀栀漀甀氀搀 戀攀 愀搀瘀椀猀攀搀 琀漀 椀渀昀漀爀洀 琀栀攀 琀攀愀挀栀攀爀猀 椀昀 愀渀礀 愀挀挀椀搀攀渀琀猀 漀挀挀甀爀 愀渀搀 栀愀瘀攀 爀攀猀甀氀琀攀搀 椀渀 戀氀攀攀搀椀渀最⸀㰀⼀椀渀猀挀爀椀瀀琀椀漀渀㸀

Title: Montre lui que tu l'aimes en êtant fidèle, en te protègeant, en l'aidant [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a drawing of a couple in traditional attire kneeling and facing each other, holding hands. In the space between their torsos, there is an object that looks like an eye, or possibly a condom, radiating beams of light or energy toward the couple. A black and white border depicts two repeating drawings of Tiki couples. In one, the Tiki couple stands arm in arm; in the other, the couple faces each other, and the male Tiki wears a condom. Poster suggests that couples that respect each other will practice safe sex, and that the Tikis play a protective role by promoting condom use.|~|Part of the "Taua noa" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FP001.
AltTitle.translated: Show them that you love them by being faithful, by protecting yourself, by helping them
Description.condition: Additional poster text: 1er prix concours de dessins: Robertson Dale, 1er prix concours de slogan "Tauo noa" Apolina Teapiki (1/12/92). Robertson Dale, 23 ans (Bora Bora) allie le traditionnel au moderne. Le couple trés typè avec des tatouages, dans des vêtements traditionnels, révèle une posture respectueuse d'écoutre à l'autre. Au centre, une boule assimilable à une alliance ou à un préservatif, irradie des rayons d'énergie. Tout s'éclaire avec le message écrit. Un clin d'oeil est donné à l'ensemble par une frise de couples de "tikis" protecteurs et porters de préservatifs.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Protection maximale [inscribed]
Description.note: Photograph of sunglasses, edge of a book, and condom in wrapper, all on the corner of a beach towel on the sand that is weighted down with a rock. Meant to convey protection in the summer sun.  The towel is in blue and brown, with a scallop pattern on the edge.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR008.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Maximum protection
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Bien utilisé, le préservatif est, lors des rapports sexuels, la meilleure protection contre le virus du sida (VIH) et les maladies sexuellement transmissibles (MST). Vérifiez que la marque NF figure sur l'emballage: cela signifie que les préservatifs ont été soumis aux contrôles de qualité de la norme française, l'une des plus strictes d'Europe. Une notice d'utilisation est délivrée dans chaque boîte. Consultez-la. Enfin, en cas de sécheresse vaginale et pour toute pénétration anale, pour éviter tout risque de rupture du préservatif, utilisez également un gel à base d'eau, en vente dans les pharmacies et dans certaines grandes surfaces. Pour en parler, Sida Info Service au 05.36.66.36. Protégez-vous du sida.
Description.caption: Protégez-vous du sida

Description.note: Two rows of four black and white drawings each, with text, illustrating step-by-step instructions for opening a condom wrapper, correctly putting on the condom, applying the gel, engaging in anal sex, removing the condom after ejaculation, and disposing of the condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR009.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Live on love and water-based gel
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Bien utilisé, le préservatif, associé à un gel exclusivement à base d'eau, est un moyen efficace de se protéger du virus du sida (VIH) et des maladies sexuellement transmissibles (MST) lors d'une pénétration anale entre hommes. Les gels à base d'eau sont en vente dans les pharmacies, certains grandes surfaces et sex-shops. Voici quelques conseils pratiques pour une efficacité optimale de ces produits.
Description.caption: Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Mine de rien, on trouve des lieux de prévention du sida à tous les coins de rue [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Protégez-vous du sida. Protégez les autres
Description.note: Text appears over a photograph of a Paris street. On the left, sticking out from a building, is a lighted "plus" sign, representing a pharmacy.  The poster stresses the importance of pharmacies as places to obtain condoms and new syringes. Pharmacists are available to listen and offer advice and support.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR012.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: You may not have noticed, but there are AIDS prevention locations on every street corner
Description.condition: Additional poster text: En un an les pharmacies ont delivré 52 millions de préservatifs, 1.8 million de Stéribox (R) et plus de 10 millions de seringues, ce qui les place en première ligne de la tutte contre le sida. Aujourd'hui les pharmaciens mettent à la disposition des usagers de drogues des seringues vendues à l'unité. C'est important, car une seringue ne doit servir qu'une fois et ne doit pas être partagée. Le pharmacien sait aussi accueillir, écouter, conseiller et orienter: il est proche de vous.
Description.caption: Votre pharmacien, acteur de la prévention du sida

Title: Vous le trouvez craquant? Dites-vous que ses "ex" aussi. [inscribed]
Description.note: To the right of the text is a photograph of an attractive young caucasian man with a bare, muscular torso, hands stuffed into the pockets of his jeans. He is smiling sweetly and seductively into the face of the viewer.  The message is, when you suddenly fall for someone and want to make love, do not forget to use a condom for protection, even from the very first time. Protect yourselves from AIDS. A colored picture of a condom is inset at the bottom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR016.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Do you find him sexy and seductive? His "ex" probably did too.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: L'été est le moment propice au coup de foudre. Parler du préservatif ensemble et l'utiliser systématiquement, permettent de se protéger. Contempler un homme, lui sussurer des mots, sortir avec lui, ne dit rien de son passé. Alors si vous craquez, n'oubliez pas le préservatif et ce, dès la première fois. Pour en parler, Sida Info Service au 05.36.66.36.

Title: Heu-reux: Anne et Philippe se réveillent tranquillement [inscribed]
Description.note: The top portion of the poster is a photograph of a man and a woman, standing on a balcony, with a house opposite in the background.  They hold bowls of steaming breakfast food. One sees the woman's face looking affectionately at the man, but his face cannot be seen. They are casually dressed, having just awakened from a night of protected sex.  The text promotes use of condoms coated with water-based gel for comfort and for protection of the condom against breakage. A colored picture of a condom is inset at the bottom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR017.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Cette nuit, ils ont fait l'amour en se protégeant. Ils se servent d'un préservatif lubrifié. Ils ajoutent un gel à base d'eau en cas de séecheresse vaginale pour ne pas gêner Anne et pour toute pénétration anale, afin d'évite tout risque de rupture du préservatif. Ces gels à base d'eau sont en vente dans les pharmacies et certaines grandes surfaces. Pour en parler, Sida Info Service au 05.36.66.36.
Alternate Title.descriptive: Happy: Anne and Philippe wake up quietly

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Bien assurer la première fois, c'est simple comme lire une B.D. [inscribed]
Description.note: To the left of the text is a four-image panel, arranged vertically, with drawings illustrating the steps in using a condom: place it on the end of the erect penis, smooth it all the way down, and remove it when finished.  The message is directed to young people who are sexually inexperienced, and seeks to reassure them that using a condom every time provides good protection. The comic-strip style of the illustrations emphasizes how easy it is to learn to use a condom and adopt this as a habit. A colored picture of a condom is inset at the bottom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR019.|~|Date on back of poster, 1997, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: To be well-insured the first time is as simple as reading a comic strip
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Cet été, ce sera peut-être la première fois. L'inexpérience, l'émotion, la hâte, la peur de ne pas assurer peuvent décontenancer lors d'un premier rapport sexuel.  Mais pour assurer, on n'est pas obligé de battre des records. En prenant son temps, en parlant ensemble, en essayant le préservatif tout seul avant, on est plus rassuré...

Title: Vous utilisez toujours une seringue neuve pour un shoot. Vous voilà donc à moitié protégé [inscribed]
Description.note: To the left of the text is a photograph of a syringe. Below and to the right of the text is a photo of a new condom, which appears in conjunction with the phrase "Protégez-vous du sida." The poster promotes the use of new syringes for every injection, and use of condoms, by explaining that both of these methods prevent transmission of the AIDS virus, other sexually transmitted diseases and hepatitis. Hotline services and telephone numbers are given. A colored picture of a condom is inset at the bottom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR021.
AltTitle.translated: You always use a new syringe to shoot up.  So there you are, half protected
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Les dommages provoqués par les drogues sont encore plus graves depuis l'apparition du sida. En utilisant une seringue neuve à chaque injection ou en ne la partageant pas, vous vous protégez de la transmission du virus du sida (VIH) par voie sanguine....

Title: Nouveaux traitements contre le sida? Je sais qu'ils sont plus efficaces mais je ne veux pas entendre parler de maladie [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous
Description.note: Part of: "Sida. Aujourd'hui on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous" campaign [AIDS. Today, we can do a lot. But nothing without you]|~|At the top is a color photograph of a young man which shows his head, shoulders and arms; his palms are pressed tightly against his ears and his facial expression suggest a refusal to hear anything. His shirt is yellow and open at the collar. In the background is a partly cloudy sky. The poster promotes the fact that effective medical treatment will slow the growth of HIV infections; these medications are synonymous with hope much more than sickness. It encourages young men to consult with a physician.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR022.
AltTitle.translated: New treatments against AIDS? I know they're more effective, but I don't want to hear any talk about sickness
Description.condition: Additional poster text: On peut se savoir atteint par le virus du sida et ne pass se résoudre à entreprendre un traitement.  Pas facile, alors qu'on se sent parfaitement bien, de prendre des médicaments qui rappellent la réalité de la maladie et la rendent visible...|~|Along the left side in small type: AUSTRALIE R.C.S. Title: Dimanche matin à Marseille [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous
Description.note: Photo showing a wooden floor with a bag. Spilling from the bag are artifacts: plaid shorts, a billfold, pills, a subscription for AZT, and three photographs. The photo evokes scenes from the motion picture Dimanche matin à Marseille, which consists of three film shorts named after the main characters in each: Renaud, Catherine, Béranger. The film shorts cover episodes from the lives of three people whose lives have been touched by AIDS.|~|Credits: Mario Fanfani (director); Jean-Pierre Bacri, Christiane Cohendy, Charles Berling, Fatiha Cheriguene, Sara Louis, Jean-Benoît Terral.|~|Part of: "Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous" campaign [AIDS. Today, we can do a lot. But nothing without you]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR025.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Sunday morning in Marseille
Description.condition: Additional poster text: AIDES-Provence et HB Productions present ... Dimanche matin à Marseille, 3 courts métrages de Mario Fanfani. Avec le soutien financier du Ministère de l’emploi et de la solidarité--Secrétariat d’état à la santé; du Comité français d’éducation pour la santé; de la DDASS des Bouches-du-Rhône; du Conseil Regional Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur; du Conseil Général des Bouches-du-Rhône, de la ville de Marseille; de l’Assistance Publique-Hôpitaux de Marseille.

AltTitle.translated: AIDS. Solidarity should be as simple as a child's game, even for adults

Title: Ruban disparaît? Pas le Sida [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous
Description.note: Depicts a column of four AIDS ribbons against a white background, a progression from bright red fading to nearly-white (or transparent). Suggests that while the AIDS remembrance ribbon may fade away, AIDS remains. Encourages AIDS awareness.|~|Part of: "Sida. Aujourd'hui, on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous" campaign [AIDS. Today, a lot can be done--but nothing without you]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR027.
AltTitle.translated: Ribbon disappears? [But] not AIDS
Description.condition: Additional poster text: 1er Décembre 1998 Journée mondiale de lutte contre le sida [World AIDS Day, 1998]

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nuit était belle, le ciel étoilé et Shéhérazade sortit un preservatif [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Pour que votre histoire d’amour reste un conte de fées
Description.note: Cartoon picture in the style of the 1992 Walt Disney film, Aladdin. Depicts a night scene, with Sheherazade on the balcony of a room having sex with the prince. In her hand is a condom. On the floor lies the book, Les mille et une nuits.|~|Part of: "Pour que votre histoire d’amour reste un conte de fées" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR028.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Night was beautiful, the sky was starry, and Sheherazade took out a condom
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Car c'était une jeune fille moderne qui savait parfaitement que le corps d'une femme est huit fois plus réceptif au virus du sida. Shéhérazade était de nature joyeuse, mais elle refusait de plaisanter avec ces choses là. The prince aprécia chez elle ce trait de charactère... Si comme Shéhérazade vous souhaiter engager le dialogue, parler de protection avec votre partenaire. SIDA Info Service vous écouter et vous conseille.

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Douce Peau d'Ane dit: Avant d'aller plus loins, mon prince, prenons des précautions [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Pour que votre histoire d’amour reste un conte de fées
Description.note: A cartoon parody of a scene from the Charles Perrault fairy tale, Donkey-Skin. Shows the kitchen table in a rustic cabin, where Donkey-Skin is about to have sex with the prince. The text encourages women to practice safe sex.|~|Part of: "Pour que votre histoire d’amour reste un conte de fées" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR029.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Sweet Donkey-Skin says, 'Before going any farther, my prince, let's take some precautions'
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Peau d'Ane ne hésita pas à mettre elle-même un préservatif à son prince car elle était bien consciente que le corps d'une femme est huit fois plus receptif au virus de sida. ... Si comme Peau d'Ane vous souhaiter engager le dialogue, parler de protection avec votre partenaire.

Title: C'est parce qu'il y a des raisons d'espérer qu'il faut continuer. Restons unis dans l'espoir [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photo showing the faces of a young man and woman. The man's head is bowed; the woman faces the camera. Neither is smiling. in the foreground, against a blue background, is the poster title. In the lower right corner is a red AIDS ribbon. Encourages unity in the struggle against AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR030.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: It is because there are reasons for hope that we must go on. Let us remain united in hope
Description.condition: Additional poster text: 1er Décembre, Journée mondiale de lutte contre le sida|~|Translation of additional poster text: Produced in conjunction with World AIDS Day, December 1st.

Title: Après tout, c'était une bonne soirée [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Protégez vous du sida. Protégez les autres
Description.note: Poster promotes condom use to prevent transmission of the HIV virus.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Protégez les autres" campaign.
AltTitle.translated: After all, it was a good night
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Pour une fois, je peux me passer de préservatif; ça ne va pas me tuer. Vous pensez avoir autant de vies que sur votre console de jeux? Protégez-vous du sida; protégez les autres.|~|Translation of additional poster text: For one time, I could forget the condom; it wouldn't kill me. Do you think you have as many lives as in your video game? Protect yourself from AIDS; protect others.

Title: Demain, 3 minutes de soleil en moins [inscribed]

On en meurt encore" campaign [AIDS. People still die from it]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR033.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Tomorrow, three minutes less sun
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Demain, 12 personnes de plus contaminées par le virus de sida en France. [Tomorrow, 12 more people contaminated with the AIDS virus in France.]

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: New calendar project, calendar of people who lived with AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Bottom half of poster shows calendar styled like a day planner, with name of each month highlighted in red, and with first names of AIDS victims in black. The calendar is shaped like the letter T, and forms the beginning of the word "time." Invites readers to participate in the calendar project.|~|Presented in conjunction with the XI International Conference on AIDS, Vancouver, 1996; updated in 1999. First model of the calendar was published in issue no. 23 (Jan. 1996) of 'Sida Tout Va Bien,' the newsletter of the Association positifs.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR035.
Description.condition: Additional poster text, located on top half of poster, describing the development of the calendar: In order not to forget the people who have fought AIDS, to show the spread of the epidemic and to warn as many people as possible, particularly those who still feel that AIDS does not concern them, we wish to create a new calendar, adding to the one already in existence, where each day is given the first name of a person who died of AIDS....

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sol En Si, SOLlidarité ENfants SIda [inscribed]
Description.note: Yellow and orange background with black text. Color illustration of part of a house and the sun. Promotes the services of Sol En Si, a support group created in 1990 to help families with children who are HIV positive or have AIDS. Poster lists telephone numbers for Sol En Si sites in Paris, Bobigny, Bois Colombes, Marseille, Nice and Cayenne.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR036.
AltTitle.translated: Sol En Si, Solidarity [for] Children [with] AIDS
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Association de soutien aux familles séropositives ou touchées par le Sida. [Support group for HIV-positive families or families affected by AIDS.]

Title: Parce que c’est souvent difficile d’en parler … Sida Info Service, 24 heures, 7 jours [inscribed]

Advertises the hotline service provided by Sida Info Service.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR037.
AltTitle.translated: Because it is often difficult to talk about it ... Sida Info Service, 24/7
Description.condition: Additional poster text: écouter, informer, orienter, soutenir. Appel anonyme et gratuit. [Listen, inform, direct, support. Calling is anonymous and free.]

Title: T’as rien oublie? [inscribed]
Description.note: Blue-green background with black text. Cartoon of whistling seal holding hat shaped like a condom. AltTitle.translated: Have you forgotten anything?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Le sauna c’est le repos et la détente, profitons-en, en toute sécurité. Bon Sauna !|~|Translation of additional poster text: The sauna means rest and relaxation; let's benefit from it in complete safety. Happy Sauna!

Title: Et le préservatif, vous attendez quoi pour en parler? [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Sida. Aujourd'hui on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous
Description.note: Pink background with black and white text. Picture of a night scene, a tent among trees; silhouette of couple seated in tent. Poster humorously suggests that rather than talking about favorite dance styles, the couple should discuss safe sex.|~|Part of: "Sida. Aujourd'hui on peut faire beaucoup. Mais rien sans vous" campaign [AIDS. Today, we can do a lot. But nothing without you]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR039.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: And the condom… What are you waiting for to talk about it?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Pour moi, y'a que la techno pour danser.--Attends la techno c'est cool mais faudrait pas oublier la transe. --Mais non, la transe c'est naze, à la rigeur le trip hop --Quoi! le trip hop? c'est juste du hardcore vaguement mélodique...

Title: Jai deux amours, je les protège [inscribed]

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR050.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Publisher.publisherName: Comité français d'éducation pour la santé|~|France. Ministère de l'emploi et de la solidarité
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: SIDA. Vous avez pris un risque? Vous avez des doutes? Vous êtes au bon endroit pour en parler [inscribed]
Description.note: A black and white photograph of part of a woman's face, focusing on her eyes, over multicolored text on a turquoise background. Poster suggests that women who have put themselves at risk for HIV infection should be tested. Poster provides hotline number for SIDA Info Service.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR051.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS. Have you taken a risk? Do you have doubts? You are in the right place to talk about it.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Toxico dependance? Reconquerir sa liberté [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph taken from the waist down of a person sitting on a bench, with clasped hands dangling between their legs. Poster suggests the need to conquer drug addiction, and lists an address and phone number for a drug treatment center.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR052.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Toxic dependance? Reconquer your freedom

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Face au sida, une attitude différente peut changer votre vie [inscribed]
Description.note: A color photograph of a man jumping up in the air. Additional poster text describes services provided by AIDES. Poster suggests that, with services available for people with AIDS, there is no reason to have an attitude of despair.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR054.

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Publisher.publisherName: Agence française de lutte contre le Sida|~|Aides (Association)
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Hey pote, passe-moi une capote! Toujour avec un gel à base d'eau [inscribed]
Description.note: A black and white photograph of two young black men, one leaning on the other. The poster targets young gay men and encourages the use of condoms and water-based lubricants to prevent the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR055.
AltTitle.translated: Hey pal, pass me a condom! Always with a water-based lubricant

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sida Info Service : nous avons le devoir de réponse [inscribed]
Description.note: Eight black and white portraits: interracial couple; woman with her hair tied back wearing a cardigan; man wearing a black sports coat; gay male couple; man wearing a checkered oxford; middle aged couple; woman wearing a jean-jacket; man wearing a leather jacket with a hoop earring in one ear and a stud in the other. Poster provides the phone number for a 24-hour AIDS hotline, Sida Info Service, and suggests it as a resource for questions about HIV and AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR056.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS Info Service : we have a duty to respond

Title: Et le préservatif, vous attendez quoi pour en parler? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a color photograph of a man and woman leaning on the hood of a car on a cliff and looking out over the ocean. Additional text indicates that they are talking about the relationship of individual countries to the European Union. Poster suggests that it is more important to talk about condoms and safe sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR058.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: And the condom, why are you waiting to speak about it?

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Virus du sida ne se transmet pas en pénétrant dans le bureau d'une collègue [inscribed]
Description.note: Depicts a door handle covered by a condom. Poster addresses a misperception about the transmission of the AIDS virus. Poster suggests through the image (suggestive representation of a penis) and text (penetrating) the actual mode of transmission of the AIDS virus through sex, and the importance of using a condom as protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR059.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS virus is not transmitted by penetrating the office of a female colleague

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences

Description.note: Depicts pens covered with condoms inside a pencil holder. Poster addresses a misperception about the transmission of the AIDS virus. Poster suggests through the images (suggestive representations of penises) and text (sucking) the actual mode of transmission of the AIDS virus through sex, and the importance of using a condom as protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR060.
Alternate Title.descriptive: AIDS virus is not transmitted by sucking a colleague's pen

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Vous avez des doutes... Des reponses pour y voir plus clair [inscribed]

The Services are confidential, anonymous, and free.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR062.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ceci ne transmet pas le virus du sida [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster presents a sequence of illustrations which show how HIV cannot be transmitted: man shaking hands; man laying on a couch with his cat and swatting a fly; man on a ladder in a pool wearing a swim cap with a fish next to him; man covered in soap suds standing next to a hanger and washing machine; man exiting a public restroom; man holding a hammer jumping to reach a nail; two children playing with blocks; man drinking from a public water fountain; man running with flowers in his hand for a hospital visit; man sitting at a table with a plate in front of him holding a large knife and fork; man and woman hugging and kissing; man surrounded by two large telephone receivers; doctor examining a patient; man donating blood.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. En France, le test n'est pas obligatoire sauf à l'occasion des dons de sang, de sperme ou d'organes. On ne peut donc pas l'exiger de vous. [Voluntarily taking an HIV test is responsible behavior. In France, the test isn't mandatory except when donating blood, sperm or organs. It is not otherwise required of you.]

Description.condition: Additional poster text: info+ Bei Menschen mit HIV gelten besondere Dosierungs- empfehlungen für die Syphilis-behandlung, außerdem schreitet bei ihnen eine unbehandelte infektion schneller fort- bei einer Syphilisdiagnose ist daher ein HIV-Test sinnvoll. [For people with HIV, special dosage is recommended to treat Syphilis. It is a step closer to treating the infection quickly. When diagnosed with Syphilis, an HIV test is useful.]|~|Additional poster text: Kondome schützen vor HIV. Bei Syphilis bieten sie allerdings keinen 100%igen Schutz. Frage bei Haut- und Schleimhautveränderungen einen Arzt deines Vertrauens und lass dichregelmäßig untersuchen, denn eine Syphilis wird oft nicht bemerkt. Zudem erhöht eine unbehandelte infektion das HIV-Übertragungsrisiko. [Condoms protect against HIV. With Syphilis they do not offer 100% protection. Ask questions about skin and mucous membranes to a physician whom you are comfortable with, and go for a regular checkup as Syphilis is often unnoticed. Besides, an untreated infection increases the HIV transmission risk.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Welt-AIDS-Tag 1. Dezember
Description.note: Photograph of a red ribbon badge, which is the symbol of solidary and support for all people suffering with AIDS and HIV. World AIDS Day began in 1988, and has been held every year since, always on December 1.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW092.
AltTitle.translated: World AIDS Day, 1 December
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Gemeinsame Rechte -- Gemeinsame Verantwortung [Mutual rights -- Mutual responsibility] (theme of World AIDS Day in 1995)|~|Additional poster text: Die Rote Schleife steht für Solidarität mit Menschen, die von AIDS betroffen sind. Zeigen Sie Anteilnahme und Engagement; Unterstützen Sie mit einter Spende die AIDS-Stiftungen und die Deutsche AIDS-Hilfe (Konto 4004 Stichwort: Welt-AIDS-Tag, bei allen Geldinstituten) oder andere Initiativen, die sich für Menschen mit HIV und AIDS einsetzen. [The red ribbon stands for solidarity with those afflicted with AIDS. Show your participation and commitment: lend your support by donating to AIDS charities and the Deutsche AIDS-Hilfe. (Account 4004, Keyword: Welt-AIDS-Tag, at any banking institution) or to any other initiatives on behalf of those afflicted with AIDS and HIV.]

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Urlaub von der Treue is das Ende der Sicherheit
Description.note: Photograph depicting a man with his arm around one woman, turning to look suggestively at another woman. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW105.
AltTitle.translated: A vacation from fidelity is the end of security
Description.condition: Die Bundeszentrale für gesundheitliche Aufklärung informiert ... [The Center for Health Information advises ...]|~|AIDS bekommt man nicht wie einen Schnupfen. Anstecken kann man sich bei ungeschütztem Sex mit unbekannten Partnern. Deshalb gilt im Urlaub, wie überall: Partnerschaftliche Treue ist der Beste Schutz vor AIDS. Wenn Sie noch Fragen haben, rufen Sie an: 0221/892031 [You don't get AIDS like you do a cold. You can be infected by having unprotected sex with strangers. So when on vacation, as always: Fidelity is the best protection against AIDS. For more information, call: 0221/892031]

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nicht jede Verbindung ist eine feste
Description.note: Depicts a young woman on the telephone, one hand caressing the phone cord. She is wearing a cocktail dress and has a string of pearls around her neck. The poster text "eine Feste Verbindung" is being used in reference to a clear telephone connection, which relates directly to the poster's graphic. The phrase can also be interpreted as "a permanent connection," as in a permanent relationship with another person. The poster is then suggesting that not all relationships are free of "static" or are permanent, indicating that no one should be taking chances with a sexual partner. Protection should always be used.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Additional poster text: Dem Leben zuliebe.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW126.
AltTitle.translated: Not every connection is a clear one

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Mann/Mann
Description.note: This "Steck" cartoon depicts two naked men with their arms around each other, seated on a hilltop, smiling. Snow is falling around them. However, they are sitting under the "protection" of a condom, which is keeping them safe from the snowfall, and safe from the darkness, as light is eminating down from the condom above them. Since the snowflakes are suggestive of sperm, the two men can be thought of as being kept safe from the transmission of AIDS through the use of a condom.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW135.
AltTitle.translated: Man man

Since the snowflakes can be suggestive of sperm, the couple can be thought of as being kept safe from the transmission of AIDS through the use of a condom.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Poster held by Louise M. Title: AIDS: Das kommt in den besten Familien vor
Description.note: Poster is a brochure depicting toys and an article explaining that AIDS does not discriminate between classes and ages. Article brings up AIDS awareness and the social stigma of somone who is infected.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW137.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS: it happens in the best of families

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Aids und Familie
Description.note: Poster has a short story for the words,Worries,  Hope, Memories, Support, Gossip. For worries, Ina is an infected single mother who worries about the care of her daughter when she dies. For hope, Margot and Peter have taken on four-year old Tobias whose parents died of AIDS, they hope there will be a cure soon. For memories, Marianne lost both her sons to AIDS, she is having a difficult time adjusting, even though they died some time ago. For support, Jorge was accompanied by his friend Marcus when Jorge found out he had AIDS; Marcus is supportive, non-judgmental and not HIV-infected. For gossip, Kai lives in a small town, the last time his brother, Manfred, visited his family, they were shocked at his sickly appearance. His parents worry about what the neighbors are thinking. Poster sums up their stories, bringing up issues and questions. AIDS is a big challenge to those infected and their friends and families. They're dealing with the situation. How to cope with the terminally ill. A loved one will die, they wonder why it happened to them and how they can help.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW137b.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS and the family

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS ist auch Männersache
Description.note: The poster is part of a published brochure entitled "AIDS ist auch Männersache." Divided by color into quadrants, the poster features four pictures: condoms (on an orange background), a man's hand holding a small barbell (on a blue background), an open lipstick container (on a pink background), and four Teddy bears (on a green background). In the lower right corner, a small AIDS ribbon appears next to the logo for the German anti-AIDS campaign slogan.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaign in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance].|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW138.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS is also an issue for men
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Geshundeit. Sexualität. Familie. Prävention. Kondome. Weltaidstag 1. Dezember [Health. Sexuality. Family. Prevention. Condoms. World AIDS Day, December 1].

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Warum verlangt Leda das von mir?
Description.note: Poster is a comical cartoon drawing of a swan, with a condom on its beak, lamenting "Why does Leda expect me to do this?" The obvious reference is to the classical Greek myth, "Leda and the Swan," in which Zeus transforms himself into a Swan in order to lay with Leda (and impregnate her). The condom symbolizes protection against pregnancy, and could also be considered a symbol of protection against AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases.|~|Part of the public AIDS campaigns in Germany: Gib AIDS keine Chance [Don't give AIDS a chance]|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW139.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Why does Leda expect me to do this?

The background is classic, beautiful and romanesque, but is slightly out of focus. The camera is clearly accentuating the actions of the young men, and is suggestive of the sexual activity that is about to take place. The poster text suggests that feelings of lust are natural and beautiful, and that the use of protection should be considered to be a natural part of sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. The painting shows four bald men in different colored shirts and blue pants standing around a fifth man, who is naked and seated. One of the standing men is counseling the seated man, the others are thinking and reacting.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW173.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Solidarität ist gefragt, nicht nur in Krisensituationen.|~|Translation: Despair and silence don't help. We don't want to be heartless, but support and help when you need it. Solidarity is required, not only in crisis situations.

Miteinander reden, gemeinsam etwas unternehmen macht Mut.  Und Spass!  Es gibt viele Angebote für positive Frauen: Selbsthilfegruppen, Freizeitaktivitäten, Gesprächstreffs.  Die Mitarbeiterinnen der AIDS-Hilfen können Dir sagen, wo du sie findest.

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW187.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional text: Geschlechtskrankheiten sind in kommen. Benutze Kondome. Sie verringern das Ansteckungsrisiko-schützen aber nicht völlig. Achte auf deinen Körper. Bei Veränderungen frage einen Arzt Deines Vertrauens. Lass dich regelmässig untersuchen. Viele Geschlechtskrankheiten machen sich kaum oder erst spät bemerkbar.|~|Translation: There are a lot of sexually transmitted diseases around. Use a condom. They reduce the risk of infection but not completely. Pay attention to your body. If you notice changes ask a doctor you trust. Get regular check-ups. Many diseases are only noticeable too late.

Suggests that people can be brought together because of HIV and this is more important than their differences.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW188.

Description.condition: Niemand ist gern einsam.  Zum zusammensein gehören Unabhängigkeit, Freiheit, Klarheit über eigene Ansprüche und Wünsche.Drum nimm dein Leben in die eigenen Hände.  Du bist verantwortlich - nicht nur beim Sex.  Sei du selbst, ohne faule Kompromisse.Für dich und deine Partner.  Für den Spass, die Liebe und das Leben mit anderen.

Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW191.

Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW193.

Title: Bedürfnisse haben Recht. [inscribed]
Description.note: Color depiction divided into three panels--one on top and two below.  Each panel consists of a photograph of a woman.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW197.
AltTitle.translated: Needs have rights
Description.condition: Text: Hiv positiv. Lebensqualität für dich vielleicht ein Fremdwort? Aber es gibt eine Reihe von staatlichen Zuschüssen und Vergünstigungen. Verzichte nicht aus Scham oder Angst auf das, was dir zusteht. Es sind keine Almosen -- du hast ein Recht darauf! Beratung, Information und tatkräftige Unterstützung bekommst du bei den Mitarbeiterinnen der AIDS-Hilfen. [HIV positive. Is quality of life a foreign word to you? But there is a set of state subsidies and privileges. Don't do without things you're entitled to because of shame or fear. This isn't charity -- you have a right to it! You can get consultation, information and strong support from AIDS-Hilfe employees.]

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Amit az AIDS-ről és megelőzéséről tudni kell
Description.note: Poster provides extensive textual information about AIDS & HIV transmission and prevention, including the role of drug and alcohol abuse in promoting risky behavior. A cartoon bird is depicted bringing information to the reader, and a cartoon monster represents the virus itself. Text also provides information about hotlines and other services, some anonymous, that provide information, testing and counseling services.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item HU001.
Format.dimensions: 43 cm. x 61 cm. (17 in. x 24 in.)

Darling Biomedical Library. Title: Beste Bart, we willen even zeggen dat je bij ons moet blijven werken [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a heartfelt message of sympathy to a student who is fighting for his life. The form of a letter tells the person that others care and they want to be in contact. To understand better, be willing to learn and listen to the notion of AIDS. "dat je bij ons" on the poster is blue while the rest of the letter is written in yellow. Perhaps the letter is written by more than one student.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE004.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Dear Bart, we just want to say that you must continue to fight for us
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Begrip En AIDS Horen Bij Elkaar.|~|Translated poster text: Listen to the concept of AIDS together.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Bé lekker ding [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster has a pink rolled up condom on a silver background. Condoms are lubricated with a protective coating and are available for a useful purpose. Protection is accessible, however, using them depends on one's choice. Hence to be safe or not to be safe, is the question.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE005.
AltTitle.translated: It's a nice thing
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Ik vrij veilig of ik vrij niet.|~|Translated poster text: I rather be safe or I rather not.

Publisher.publisherName: Nederlands Instituut  voor Alcohol en Drugs
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Even aan denken [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster depicts a syringe with a red exclamation mark used for drugs. As a sign of danger, the exclamation mark emphasizes that the equipment is unsafe. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE006.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Title: Als je later kinderen wilt: gebruik dan nu een condoom! [inscribed]

Poster encourages using a condom now to protect a woman's ability to have children in the future.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE015.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Name.creator: SOA AIDS Nederland
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Wil je geen soa als souvenir? Gebruik dan een condoom! [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster recommends using a condom to prevent long term consequences (souvenir, keepsake as in the poster) of sexually transmitted diseases. Background is green to show emotional connection with safety. Poster assures one's security with the usage of protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE016.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Met syfilis ben je vatbaarder voor hiv. Gebruik daarom een condoom! [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster informs the linkage between sexually transmitted infections and the HIV virus. HIV transmission is more likely for those infected with STIs. Therefore, the act of using a condom can prevent one and stop the risk for another.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE017.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: With Syphilis, you are more susceptible for HIV. So use a condom!
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Hiv dringt MAKKELIJKER het lichaam binnen als je een andere soa hebt.|~|Translated poster text: HIV penetrates the body MORE EASILY if you carry another STD.

Title: Weet je zeker dat je vriendje geen chlamydia heeft? Gebruik toch maar een condoom! [inscribed]

AltTitle.translated: If you cannot be faithful, at least be faithful to life. Always use a condom

Publisher.publisherName: Portugal. Commissão Nacional de Luta Contra a SIDA
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: VIH/SIDA: os factos [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster presents the facts about the transmission of HIV and AIDS. Divided into two parts, poster presents a sequence of images to separate the facts from the misperceptions. AIDS is transmitted through: unprotected sex, contact with contaminated blood, from mother-to-child during pregnancy and breast-feeding, and sharing of needles. AIDS is not transmitted through: food or silverware, mosquito bites, coughing and sneezing, shaking hands and hugging, use of public restrooms, safe sex (condom), and social contact.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO004.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: HIV/AIDS: the facts
Description.condition: Additional poster text: A SIDA não tem cura... Não discrimine!|~|Translated poster text: There is no cure for AIDS ... Do not discriminate!

Description.caption: AIDS is watching you. Take precautions. Use a condom

Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Papua New Guinea|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS: we are all at risk
AltTitle.other: Protect yourself from AIDS|~|AIDS is the most serious health threat our country faces. Every month 100 Papua New Guineans will catch the AIDS virus. Our sons, daughters, brothers, sisters, wantoks are all at risk.
Description.note: Top half of the poster is textual, with subheadings "How do you catch the AIDS virus?" "Why do we need to protect ourselves?" and "Let's talk about AIDS." Lower half of the poster depicts Dr. Clement Malau of the PNG National AIDS Council sitting at a desk. On the desk is a laptop computer with a map of Papua New Guinea on its screen, a microscope, and specimen tubes. The poster suggests the importance of open communication and scientific understanding of the causes and prevention of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PP001.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: A mí me importa ... Y a ti? [inscribed]
Description.note: Additional poster text: Día mundial del SIDA. 1 de Diciembre de 2001. "Debemos implicar a los jóvenes que viven con el VIH/SIDA en la lucha contra la epidemia. Después de todo, ellos son quienes mejor saben lo que significa vivir con SIDA". Kofi Annan, Secretario General de las Naciones Unidas. "Párate un momento, escucha y aprende todo lo que puedas acerca del VIH/SIDA. La prevención y la vida... ¡están en tus manos!" Joey DiPaolo, educador sobre el SIDA que vive con VIH.|~|Picture of Joey DiPaolo with Kofi Annan holding an open book titled "Living Proof."|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP001.
AltTitle.translated: I care... Do you?

Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|Condoms|~|AIDS (Disease)--Risk factors|~|Awareness|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Publisher.publisherName: Spain. Ministerio de Sanidad y Consumo
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Si Da. No Da. No cambies tu vida por el SIDA [inscribed]
Description.note: Additional poster text. Si Da: Intercambiarse la maquinilla de afeitar y otros objetos personales cortantes. Transmisión de la madre al feto. Tatuaje con agujas sin esterilizar. Hacer el amor con portadores (Hombre-mujer). Relaciones homosexuales con portadores. Utilizar la misma jeringuilla. Intercambiarse el cepillo de dientes. No Da: Practicar cualquier tipo de relaciones sexuales utilizando perservativo. Bañarse con portadores. (Duchas, piscinas, etc.). Las picaduras de insectos. Jugar con portadores. Beber del mismo vaso o la misma botella. Darse la mano. Besarse and abrazarse. Cambiarse la ropa. Utilizar los mismos servicios que los portadores.|~|Images of female and male gender symbols engaging in different activities. On one side of the poster, they are depicting and describing activities that can increase the risk of transmission of the HIV virus. Activities such as having unprotected sex with a person infected with the virus, sharing needles, toothbrushes or razors. One the other half, the symbols are depicting and describing activities through which transmission is not possible or the risk of transmission is decreased. Some of these activities include having protected sex, kissing, hugging and shaking hands.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP002.
AltTitle.translated: Yes this transmits. No this doesn't transmit. Don't change your life because of AIDS

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: SIDA: hoy X hoy, la única, vacuna: información y prevención [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP009.|~|Poster advocates arming oneself with knowledge about preventive measures as the most effect "vaccine" against AIDS. It depicts some of the misperceptions about AIDS transmission: you can't get it by kissing, holding hands, playing with an AIDS patient, using the same utensils as an AIDS patient, or using the same toilet. It also depicts ways to prevent contracting AIDS: don't use the same razor or toothbrush, use a condom, and use unused syringes.
AltTitle.translated: Day X Day, the only, vaccination: information and prevention
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Asi no se contrae el SIDA [with depictions of how AIDS can't be contracted underneath]; Asi se previene el SIDA [with depictions of how to prevent it].

Subject.conceptTopic: Mapplethorpe, Robert|~|Homosexuality, Male|~|Gay culture|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|Marginality, Social|~|Haring, Keith|~|Mercury, Freddie|~|AIDS (Disease)--Switzerland
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Escludere per l'AIDS? Escluso!
Description.note: Shows a nude man floating in front of a triptych of stars, a moon, and a cloud with an angel. Below him is an assortment of items associated with gay culture (a book of Robert Mapplethorpe's photography, a Freddie Mercury album, a Keith Haring painting) as well as holiday decor and wrapped presents. The poster may represent the gifts of gay culture to the mainstream and argue against thinking of the gay community as separate and the only part of society that has to deal with AIDS. It also suggests the decimation of the gay community by AIDS, as represented by the three artists, each of whom died of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ009.
AltTitle.translated: To exclude because of AIDS? Excluded!

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ohne? Ohne mich
Description.note: A color photograph shows a man dressed in a suit and tie seated behind a desk in an office, surrounded by shelves full of books. His closed right hand is raised with thumb pointing up in a "thumbs up" sign; on  his thumb is a condom. The word "ohne" (without) is next to the condom. The man is probably in his thirties, wears glasses, and has a professional desk job, perhaps as an archivist, lawyer or accountant. The message is that a mature, well-educated professional gay man will not have sex unless condoms are used for protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ018.
AltTitle.translated: Without it? Without me
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Eine Präventionskampagne der Aids-Hilfe Schweiz in Zusammenarbeit mit dem Bundesamtes für Gesundheitswesen.|~|cR Basel

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Gay men|~|Safe Sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sans? Sans moi.
Description.note: A color photograph shows a good-looking young man seated in the driver's seat of a red convertable sports car with the top down, parked on the street in front of a building in a city. His left arm rests on the top of the door, while his right arm is toward the viewer; his right hand is closed in a "thumbs up" sign, with a condom on his thumb. He wears a black leather jacket and his sunglasses are shoved back on the top of his black curley hair.  The message is that a sporty young gay man will not have sex unless condoms are used.|~|A decal on the windshield shows "92" possibly a year of registration of the automobile.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ019.
AltTitle.translated: Without it? Without me.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Campagne de prévention de l'Aide Suisse contre le SIDA, en collaboration avec l'Office fédéral de la santé publique.|~|cR Basel

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Wir schützen uns, weil wir uns lieben
Description.note: Two muscular young men, clad only in undershorts and shorts, are enjoying a picnic in a grain field.  In the foreground, one man lies on his back on a blanket, shorts open in front and pulled down to reveal his undershorts. He holds hands and looks fondly into the face of his lover, who is sitting up next to him, dressed only in undershorts.  Their eyes display love for each other.  An open picnic basket sits nearby, and one can see some bread, some wine, some watermelon, and some red condoms. The scene is one of idyllic pleasure, and also of safety and security.|~|Part of "Stop AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ020.
AltTitle.translated: We protect each other, because we love one another
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Eine Präventionskampagne des Bundesamtes für Gesundheitswesen, in Zusammenarbeit mit der Aids Hilfe Schweiz.|~|SEILER DDB NEEDHAM/cR

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Condoms|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nous nous protégeons parce que nous nous aimons
Description.note: A color photograph shows a man and a woman playfully relaxing in a small boat, secluded by some reeds at the edge of a large lake. The man, dressed in undershorts, is leaning back on a bench in the boat, looking at the woman and teasing her by dangling her bra from one outstretched hand.  The woman is facing him, seated on another bench, and is splashing him with a little water from the lake. She is covered by some clothing draped from breast to hips. Next to the man is a straw bag draped with an article of clothing; on top are seen two red unopened condoms.  The scene is one of sexy playfulness, love, fun, safety and security because the man uses condoms for protection.|~|Part of "Stop AIDS" campaign|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ021.
AltTitle.translated: We protect each other because we love one another
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Campagne de prévention de l'Office fédéral de la santé publique, en collaboration avec l'Aide Suisse contre le Sida.|~|SEILER DDB NEEDHAM/cR
