Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ich habe Aids. Ich habe Angst vor Ihrer Angst vor mir
Description.note: A black and white photo in which a young man stands alone against an empty background, on the right side of the photo. He wears jeans, a long sleeved shirt with open collar, and a vest open at the front.  With dark hair and a large dark moustache, he looks dolefully toward the viewer, left hand placed on his waist, right hand in his jeans pocket. The photo evokes a sombre mood of lonliness and fear, which encourages to viewer to think about being in the same state as the young man, and emphasizes the need to stop AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ026.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: I have AIDS. I'm afraid of the fear you have of me

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: En tant qu'homme malade du Sida ne suis-je plus qu'un malade du Sida?
Description.note: A black and white photograph in the center of which stands a man looking directly at the viewer, his left hand in his trousers pocket, with a thoughtful, inquiring, and vaguely challenging look on his face.  He is nicely  dressed in slacks and a long-sleeved sweater, just an ordinary man aged in his thirties, balding in front, with a goatee and moustache.  His challenge is to be seen as an individual human being, not just a sick man with AIDS.|~|Part of the "Stop AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ027.
AltTitle.translated: In my capacity as a man sick with Aids, am I nothing more than just a sick man with AIDS?

Title: Sie steht für ein neues Gefühl...
Description.note: A safety pin is shown pinned onto the lapel of a man's suit. The poster image is a black and white photo showing the left-hand side of a man's torso, from his chin to his shoulder; he is wearing a tie, a shirt with button-down collar, and a suit. Vertically along the right side of the poster are five olive-yellow boxes containing the texts, with a little safety pin image next to each one.  What the safety pin stands for are: new feelings, responsibility, solidarity, trust, and open verbal communication. If a man practices safe sex, his wearing of the safety pin would let others know that they can talk with him about it.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Transmission
Publisher.publisherName: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: How AIDS is spread
Description.note: Poster describes four ways by which AIDS is spread: sexual intercourse, contaminated medical instruments, pregnancy and blood transfusions. Illustrations depict a naked man and woman in silhouette, a man receiving medical treatment from a traditional healer, a kneeling pregnant woman, and a woman receiving a blood transfusion.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG001.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: AIDS is spread mainly through sexual intercourse with an infected person. AIDS is spread through blood contaminated instruments. AIDS is spread through infected woman during pregnancy to her unborn child. AIDS is spread through infected blood transfusion. Prevent AIDS! Have sexual intercourse with a faithful partner for life. Accept medical treatment only from trained health workers in health centres where equipment is kept sterile and blood is checked against AIDS.|~|Poster is item 7 in Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Description.caption: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Publisher.publisherName: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What does a person with AIDS look like? AIDS can look like many other diseases. Don't be confused. Don't spread rumors
Description.note: Illustrations depict 6 other diseases or conditions that can easily be misidentified as AIDS. Poster suggests that people should not assume that someone has AIDS just because they appear sick, and the importance of testing for people who suspect they have AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG002.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: AIDS or measles? AIDS or tuberculosis? AIDS or alcoholism? AIDS or malnutrition? AIDS or typhoid? AIDS or cancer? See a qualified medical person for tests if you think you or someone you know may have AIDS.|~|Item 5 in the Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Description.caption: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Publisher.publisherName: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What have you heard about AIDS? Don't guess the answers! Learn the truth about AIDS!
Description.note: Illustration depicts a young girl and boy walking. The girl is whispering in the boy's ear. Poster suggests that children should learn the facts about AIDS rather than spreading misinformation.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG003.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: What does it mean? What can we do for people who have it? How does it harm us? Can it be cured? Who can get it? What does it look like? What causes it? Which of us has it? How can we stop it?|~|Item 3 in the Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Description.caption: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Title: What am I? [inscribed]
Description.note: Background stripes of pink, green, purple, and blue; text in white & black. Depicts four rows of curios. Row 1: drawing of Freud's profile with naked man as face; toothbrush with popsicle on stick; pineapple filled with ice; bear sculpture with banana as tail. Row 2: "Ken" doll; ceramic teapot shaped as cottage; photo of gnome and pink flamingo lawn decorations; greeting card with picture of cowboy. Row 3: hand grenade; pen with photo of nude man; pastille candies with red hearts. Row 4: Bandages of the invisible man; green & blue bugs; mer-man.|~|Sponsors: Community HIV and AIDS Prevention Strategy; Gay Men’s Project; Slap fM; Gay Men Fighting AIDS; Healthy Gay Manchester; Gay Men's Health Matters; BIGUP; Yorkshire MESMAC; Naz Project London; The Network.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK014.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: I’m free ‘n’ easy and fun to pick up. I’m easily passed on. I can be invisible and damage your health. I’m a sexually transmitted disease. Most STIs are easily treated, but if left can cause serious health problems. Regular check-ups are recommended to detect STIs which may go unnoticed.

Subject.conceptTopic: Social advocacy|~|HIV-positive persons--Counseling of|~|HIV infections|~|George House Trust|~|AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Counseling of
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Our response to HIV [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster in two halves: top half has blue background; bottom half, red. Text in white. Promotes the services offered by the George House Trust. George House Trust, established in 1985 (as "Manchester AIDSline"), is one of the oldest HIV charities in the UK.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK015.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional text: Advice, befriending, campaigning, challenging discrimination, emotional support, information, peer support, representation, therapies, training.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: When Martin was told he had AIDS, his family couldn't believe it. After all, he is 64 [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of three smiling people sitting on a blanket in the grass: a middle-aged man and woman, and a young man. Poster suggests that anyone can be infected with AIDS, not just young gay men, and describes London Lighthouse as a resource for older people who are HIV-positive.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK016.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Not surprisingly they came to us. Still numb. Still protesting that they thought AIDS was only a 'young person's' illness. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. We're now helping them accept Martin's illness and carry on with their lives. Old or young. Him or her. White or black. Straight or gay. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Services for|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|Social networks|~|AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Family relationships|~|Counseling
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Their son was diagnosed HIV+. Their son went to them for support. Their son was told he wasn't their son anymore. [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a smiling middle-aged couple holding a "Happy Anniversary" cake with lit candles. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for HIV-positive people even when their families reject them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK017.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Then, their son came to us. He told us his story. We listened. We explained that his parents weren't evil. Just ignorant. Overwhelmed by fear. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. In fact, his parents are now talking to us. Which is a start. Straight or gay. Old or young. White or black. Him or her. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: She told her husband she was HIV+. He took it badly. She told her best friends. They took off [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a woman's face reflected in a mirror. She has a black eye. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for HIV-positive women whose families and friends reject them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK018.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: She told us. We listened. And listened. She told us she'd spent her life caring for others and that now, when she really needed hope, there was no-one. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. By the way, she left her husband and is now rebuilding her life again. Her or him. Young or old. Gay or straight. Black or white. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Amy's dad couldn't bring himself to accept he had AIDS. Now he can. He just can't bring himself to tell her. [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a man holding a young girl. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for HIV-positive men with families.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK019.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Could you? Probably not. That's why he came to us. We didn't tell Amy for him though. We just helped him find the strength to tell her himself. That's how we work. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. Amy doesn't understand yet, but one day, she will. Young or old. Him or her. Black or white. Straight or gay. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Derek lost his entire family to AIDS. One year later, they're still not talking to him. [inscribed]
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a bald man with his back to the viewer, talking on a telephone. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for people with AIDS when their families reject them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK020.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: That's why he called us. We always listen. We never judge. We know that family rejection can sometimes be more distressing than the illness. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. We're still trying to help Derek's family understand. Black or white. Him or her. Young or old. Straight or gay, AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.

Poster suggests the importance of speaking up against homophobia and discrimination based on sexuality, and provides contact information for 3 organizations that can provide information about sexuality and safer sex: Kiss (a Naz Project London), the Metro Centre (a centre for lesbian, gay and bisexual people), and Shakti (South Asian Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transexual Network).|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK021.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: 1 in 4 Lesbian, Gay and Bisexual people experience homophobic violence and harassment. Discrimination on the grounds of sexuality is a violation of human rights. Silence reinforces homophobic attitudes. Don't be part of the problem.

Subject.conceptTopic: Intravenous drug abuse|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|Sexual abstinence
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: There's a simple way to prevent AIDS. [inscribed]
Description.note: Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign. Picture of a woman sitting on a chair with her legs crossed. The concept of the poster is to promote abstinence from sex and drug use as an effective way to avoid the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US003.
Description.condition: There's a simple way to prevent AIDS. You want to be risk-free from AIDS? Don't have sex.  And as long as you aren't shooting drugs, you'll be fine. No worries about who's slept around, who's had blood tests, and whether your condoms are latex or not.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What have you got against a condom? [inscribed]
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS". The poster is a picture of a woman.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US004.
Description.condition: What have you got against a condom? The simple act of putting on a condom can save your life, if they're used properly and every time you have sex. For more information about AIDS and condoms, call 1-800-342-AIDS.

Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Why alcohol, crack and other drugs can put you at risk for the AIDS virus. [inscribed]
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|The poster is a blurry image of two people.  It implies that drug and alcohol use can impaire the mind, leading to behavior that puts one at risk of HIV infection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US005.
Description.condition: Why alcohol, crack and other drugs can put you at risk for the AIDS virus. They cloud your thinking. You already know that shooting up drugs and sharing needles put you at risk for AIDS. But actually, other drugs such as crack, alcohol and marijuana can put you at risk because they cloud your thinking. And when your thinking is clouded, you take foolish chances. When you're high, you may have sex. That's risky stuff. So think clearly. Don't risk AIDS. If you'd like more information on the relationship between AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases, call the National AIDS hotline. 1-800-342-AIDS. The hotline for the hearing impaired is 1-800-AIDS-TTY.

Title: You can't get AIDS- by shaking hands, or by hugging, in restaurants, or in restrooms. [inscribed]
Description.note: Black, white and red poster with pixtures of two people shaking hands, hugging, a served plate and a mens and womens restroom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US007.
Description.condition: See beyond fear. You can't get AIDS- by shaking hands, or by hugging, in restaurants, or in restrooms. AIDS doesn't spread through casual contact. Don't let fear get in the way of facts. Take the time to learn about AIDS.

Subject.conceptTopic: Sexually Transmitted Diseases--prevention & control|~|Unsafe sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Why there's a connection between sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign. The poster depicts a young man leaning into his open school locker. He is holding two books in his hands.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US008.
Description.condition: Poster text: Why there's a connection between sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS. Simple. The same type of sexual behavior that can infect you with gonorrhea, gential herpes, syphilis, and other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) can also infect you with something else... the AIDS virus. You get STDs by having sex with someone who is infected. That's bad enough. But if you continue the same unprotected sexual behavior, you could get something you can't cure. AIDS. If you'd like more information on the relationship between AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases, call the National AIDS hotline. 1-800-342-AIDS. The hotline for the hearing impaired is 1-800-AIDS-TTY.

Description.condition: Additional poster text: What have you got against a condom? The simple act of putting on a condom can save your life, if they're used properly and every time you have sex. For more information about AIDS and condoms, call 1-800-342-AIDS.

Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US011.

Title: Huellas peligrosas [inscribed]
Description.note: Depicts the arms of a couple holding hands. His arm shows needle marks from intravenous drug use. Poster suggests a relationship with risks: intravenous drug use, unprotected sex.|~|Part of "America responde al SIDA" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US012.
AltTitle.translated: Dangerous tracks
Description.condition: Ana está saliendo con un chico que se inyecta drogas. Ella está cometiendo un error grave. El puede adquirir el SIDA por compartir las agujas de las jeringas. Ana podría adquirir el SIDA por culpa de él. Ella tiene varias opciones: Hacer que él deje de inyectase drogas o buscarle ayuda profesional y tratamiento contra las drogas; u olvidarse de él, o por lo menos asegurarse que cuando tienen relaciones sexuales, él use un condón.

Name.creator: McElhaney, Jeff
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Stops transmission-fluid leaks
AltTitle.other: Use condoms. There's living proof they stop AIDS
Description.note: Poster depicts a black and white photograph of a used, stretched out condom. The image of the condom connects to the title to suggest the importance of a condom as prevention to the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US018.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Recently, top researchers filled condoms with AIDS virus-infected fluid and subjected them to pressure tests for three weeks.  No virus leaked through.  The fact of life here: Wearing condoms stops AIDS from spreading.  So try out this newfound bit of carnal knowledge: Using a condom can save your life.
Alternate Title.descriptive: [Condom] stops transmission-fluid leaks

Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service

Title: Tres razones para no andar en la calle con los muchachos
Description.note: A black and white family portrait of a latino husband and wife with their two young children, a boy and a girl. They smile happily, giving the sense of a closeknit and loving family. The intention is to make men think hard about the risks of going out with their friends and having sex with women of the streets. They could bring AIDS back to their family.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US019.
AltTitle.translated: Three reasons not to go out on the street with the guys
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Yo creía que tenía que salir con otras mujeres para pasar un buen rato. Hasta que me di cuenta que estaba arriesgando a mi familia. Es que, el SIDA está allí...|~|NAIEP 10/91 P094

They both wear jackets, and they are staring into the distance, looking ahead and not at one another.  The message is that taking drugs can lead to unsafe sexual behavior that may result in sharing the AIDS virus.|~|Part of the "American responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US020.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Find out more about how drug use and AIDS are related. Call the National AIDS hotline at 1-800-342-AIDS.|~|NAIEP P145. U.S. Government Printing Office 1993-0-738-391

Title: AIDS does not discriminate
Description.note: Poster shows a picture of nine people from different walks of life, of different ages and races, under the words "AIDS does not discriminate."|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US024.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Poster text: AIDS does not discriminate. Anyone can get AIDS from sexual contact or sharing needles with an infected person. But we know how to prevent AIDS. Learn how to protect yourself. Call 1-800-541-AIDS.

Title: AIDS is a deadly disease caused by HIV...
Description.note: Poster consists of a list of facts about AIDS and AIDS transmission.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US025.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: AIDS is a deadly disease caused by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus). To avoid infection through sex, don't have sex, or have sex only with a partner who isn't infected. An infected woman can pass HIV to her baby during pregnancy or when the baby is being born. HIV is spread by sharing needles...|~|Additional text: AIDS: facts for life

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Preocupándote del HIV no es suficiente. Más vale hacer algo
Description.note: Poster depicts the face of a pensive man.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US028.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Worrying about HIV is not sufficient. You have to do something|~|America responds to AIDS
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Si crees que estás a riesgo de estar infectado con el HIV, ahora es el momento de pensar en buscar la asesoría y hacerte examinar. Si tu resultado es positivo, trabaja junto con un médico para tomar las decisiones que serán las mehores para tí. Cuanto más rápido lo hagas, más le ayudará la atención médica. Consulta con un médico, con su departamento de salud o los otros centros locales para el SIDA. Llama al teléfono especial para el SIDA de su estado o zona local, o al teléfono nacional al 1-800-344-7432. Para las personas con impedimentos del oído, llama al 1-800-243-7889 (TTY). HIV es el virus que causa el SIDA.
Description.caption: America responde al SIDA

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: How much do your children know about AIDS?
Description.note: Poster shows a group of children of different races.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US031.
Description.condition: Poster text: How much do your children know about AIDS? Your children need an understanding of what it takes to be healthy. Schools can play an important role. If you'd like to know how you as a parent can be more involved in your school's curriculum, call 1-800-342-AIDS for information. For the hearing impaired, 1-800-AIDS-TTY. America responds to AIDS.

Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: This is the way many people deal with HIV
Description.note: Poster depicts three people acting like the "see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil" monkeys. A man covers his eyes, a woman covers her ears, and another man covers his mouth.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US032.
Description.condition: Poster text: This is the way many people deal with HIV. A lot of people don't think they have to worry about HIV. But the truth is, anyone can get HIV infection if they are sharing drug needles and syringes or having sex with an infected person. Call your State of local AIDS hotline. Or call the National AIDS Hotline at 1-800-342-AIDS. Call 1-800-243-7889 (TTY) for deaf access. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS. America Responds to AIDS.
Description.caption: America responds to AIDS

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Condoms|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|Communication
Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: If he doesn't have a condom, you just have to take a deep breath and tell him to go get one
Description.note: Poster depicts a woman sitting on a chair, with one foot on the seat of the chair.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US033.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: It's not the easiest thing in the world to say. But these days, you have to. If you're dating someone who doesn't like condoms, talk before having sex. Explain how you feel. Offer to help during the awkward moments. And if this doesn't work, ask yourself, is it worth the risk? For more information on condoms and AIDS, call 1-800-342-AIDS for answers you can count on. America responds to AIDS

Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Don't just worry about HIV. Do something about it.
Description.note: Poster depicts the face of a worried-looking African-American man.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US034.
Description.condition: Poster text: Don't just worry about HIV. Do something about it. If you think you are at risk for HIV infection, now's the time to consider counseling and testing. If you test positive, work with a doctor to make decisions that are right for you. The earlier this happens, the more medical care can help. Talk to a doctor, your health department, or other local AIDS resources. Call your State or local AIDS hotline, or the National AIDS Hotline at 1-800-342-AIDS. Call 1-800-243-7889 (TTY) for deaf access. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS. America responds to AIDS.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Some people think they come of age when they've been burnt by gonorrhea...
Description.note: Poster depicts a young African-American man standing against a chain-link fence.|~|Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US035.
Description.condition: Some people think they come of age when they've been burnt by gonorrhea, but if they've been burnt by AIDS they may never come of age. To find out more about the relationship between AIDS and VD, call the National AIDS Hotline at 1-800-342-AIDS. The hotline for the hearing impaired is 1-800-AIDS-TTY. America Responds to AIDS

Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: If you cheat on your partner you could wind up with more than just a broken heart.
Description.note: Poster depicts an African-American man and woman holding hands.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US036.
Description.condition: Poster text: If you cheat on your partner you could wind up with more than just a broken heart. With AIDS around, cheating on your partner could cheat you both out of your lives. AIDS is deadly. Even one encounter could infect you with the AIDS virus. So what started out as a harmless flirtation could turn into a deadly moment of truth. That's why it's important to know your partner. Because a broken heart is bad, but not as bad as a broken life. For more information about AIDS, call 1-800-342-AIDS. America responds to AIDS
Description.caption: America responds to AIDS

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Hey! You know what? You can't get AIDS from...
Description.note: Poster consists of nine panels with colorful drawings depicting people, mostly children, doing things that don't transmit AIDS. The poster is targeted at children.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US037.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Hey! You know what? You can't get AIDS from: eating at restaurants, using toilets in public spaces, mosquito bites, giving someone a hug or kiss, sharing food with friends, playing on playgrounds, visiting someone who is sick with AIDS, going to the doctor, AIDS is not spread by things we touch!

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Opciones para las mujeres
Description.note: Poster lists four options for lessening the chance of AIDS transmission during sex. In order of decreasing effectiveness: using a condom and spermicide;  using a condom only; using a diaphragm and vaginal spermicide; and using spermicide only. Five women are pictured individually, one may be a doctor.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US038.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Options for women
Description.condition: Poster text: Opciones para las mujeres, Qué puede hacer usted para protegerse del SIDA durante las relaciones sexuales? Absternerse o...

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Si tu has tenido sexo con dos personas...
Description.note: Poster is designed like an eye chart, with one very large word on the first line, three words in smaller type on the next line, etc. until the type is extremely tiny. The poster demonstrates the exponential nature of exposure to AIDS, as a person is susceptible to disease carried by people they have sex with, people they had had sex with before, etc.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US039.
AltTitle.translated: If you have had sex with two people...
Description.condition: Poster text: Si tu has tenido sexo con dos personas y esas dos personas cada una habia tenido sexo con otras dos personas y esas personas cada una habia tenido sexo con otras dos personas y... entonces es como si tú hubieras tenido sexo con 1,022 personas. Cualquiera pudo haberte infectado con el VIH - el virus que causa el SIDA. Para saber qué hacer ahora, llama gratis al servicio de información del VIH en Texas. 1-800-299-2437, Todas las llamadas son anónimas.|~|Translated poster text: If you have had sex with two people and each of those two people had had sex with two other people and each of those people had had sex with two other people... then it is as if you have had sex with 1,022 people. Any one of them could have been infected with HIV - the virus that causes AIDS...

Title: Tuô'i tré hãy cánh giác! SIDA : Vô phu'o'ng cú'u chu'a
Description.note: Poster features text on a blue background, surrounding a drawing of a large, ringing bell. The word "SIDA" appears in large type under the bell. The poster is "ringing" out a loud message to young people that AIDS is a dangerous, incurable disease. Youth need to be vigilant in using protection against the disease.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item VM001.
AltTitle.translated: Youth, be vigilant! AIDS. No way to cure

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS : může mít podobu anděla
Description.note: Poster is a sketch of a nude female angel from the torso up. She is looking straight ahead. The word "AIDS" is inscribed at the top in large with lettering, with the "I" in red. It appears as though the letter has been scribbled through with a red pencil. The poster serves as a caution: AIDS can be contracted from anyone, even those that appear as wonderful as an angel.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item XR001.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS : it can take the shape of an angel

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS-- nezná vyvolených!
Description.note: Artistic images and photographs of Anthony Perkins, Magic Johnson and Freddie Mercury, all of whom suffered from AIDS or HIV.|~|From campaign: Jistota věrnosti, prevence AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item XR002.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS chooses those who are ignorant!

Title: S úsměvem s kondomem

AltTitle.translated: With smiles, with kondoms

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Women, girls and HIV/AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item TR001.|~|The poster is a long narrow poster with a 2005 calander printed on it. At the top of the poster there are five photographs of smiling faces of people of different races and ages. Under the pictures there is a red AIDS ribbon with several country flags on one end of the ribbon and the logo for Caribbean Epidemiology Centre (CAREC) PAHO/WHO on the other end of the ribbon. At the bottom of the poster there are logos for the three main organizations that have published and sponsored the poster.  The websites for the Caribbean Epidemiology Centre are: www.carec.org and www.catin.org.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Women and Girls are three to six time more likely than men to contract HIV.  Take the lead NOW.  Trust in Protection.Having sex with only one partner can be high-risk behavior -- because your partner's sexual behaviour.  Trust in Protection. Marriage or living with someone does not guarantee protection against HIV infection.  Take the lead NOW.  Trust in Protection.Women and girls are twice as likely as men to contract HIV from a single act of unprotected sex, yet they leave protection up to men.  Take the lead NOW.  Trust in Protection.Men, boys and social institutions can help improve the plight of women and girls when it comes to the AIDS epidemic.  Support protection for women.Education and economic empowerment can stop the spread of HIV.  Not chance.  Not luck. Trust in protection.|~|Additional poster text: Take the lead now.  Not chance, not luck.  Trust in protection.
Description.caption: World AIDS Day

Title: ...at home ...away [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AT026.|~|The poster shows a cartoon man looking at snowglobe in his hand in which he is standing and looking at the Eiffel Tower.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text:  HIV transmission can take place either at home or while you are away.  Be prepared when you travel - think about the situations you may find yourself in.  Pack condoms and lube - they aren't available everywhere.  For more information for gay men who are traveling, check out the free booklet from your local AIDS council or visit www.afao.org.au.
Description.caption: Seeing the world?

Title: Be free [inscribed]

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT017.|~|This poster is targeted at black prostitutes and sex workers, many of whom emigrated to Italy's major cities from North Africa. The language of the text is in Italian, English and French so that it can be understood by women who came from other countries.|~|Most of the poster is a striking graphic of a woman's face, with white areas suggesting her forehead, nose and cheeks, and with blue-green eyeshadow and red lips, all against a dark brown background.  The cheeks, forehead, nose, eyes and lips are composed of very small graphics of female sex workers in various suggestive poses, but they cannot be seen distinctly until the poster is viewed close-up. The brown background suggests that the woman is black.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received  the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Translated poster text: Help line. AIDS information. Anonymous HIV testing. Unprotected sexual relations are a risk to health. Call Gruppo C of the Center for Preventive Medicine.|~|Additional poster text: 045 8622232 Help line. Informazioni AIDS. Test HIV in anonimato. Per uscire dalla prostituzione e dallo sfruttamento; For freedom from prostitution and from sexual exploitation; Pour sortir de la prostitution et de l'exploitation. I rapporti sessuali non protetti sono un rischio per la salute. Chiama il Gruppo C del Centro di Medicina Preventiva. Safe sex only [in background of poster].

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS in the world. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster shows a map of the world and the numbers of people infected with HIV in the major regions of the world.  It shows the total number of people infected, and then breaks down the information into categories of men, women, and children infected with HIV.  There is also a bar graph of the statistics in reference to industrialized countries and developing countries.  There is also a timeline visually displaying the growing numbers of AIDS infected people through the years.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: The pandemic and the response; The Pandemic: by the year 2000, 38 to 110 million adults may be HIV infected--an effective response can make the difference; The challenge: the gap between the pandemic and the current response is growing rapidly.  The world needs a new approach--A new health strategy for AIDS; Cumulative HIV infections as of January 1, 1993.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Down low [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster is of a well dressed African American couple getting propositioned by a seedy looking African American male in gangster attire.  Poster suggests that many people are in denial that HIV is so prevalent and ignore the issue.  Poster states that doing this can be fatal, and one should get tested for HIV.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Two-thirds (63%) of all women reported with AIDS were African American. -Center for Disease Control & Prevention; What you don't know can kill you...;...Get the facts.  Get tested!; For more information about HIV/STD testing, contact your local health department.

Title: For a person living with HIV Cotrimoxazole can be life saving! [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SA003.|~|Background in orange and black; text in white & black. Picture of a man with folded arms. He is asking: “Have you tested HIV positive? Description.condition: Additional poster text: Cotrimoxazole is also called Bactrim, Purbac, Cozole, Nucotrim... Each company gives it a different name. This medicine can prevent PCP pneumonia, Toxoplasmosis stroke, illnesses common with HIV. Ensure a constant supply of Cotrimoxazole at your clinic!|~|Additional poster text: Support voluntary HIV counselling and testing. There are direct benefits if you know your HIV status. There are medicines that improve your health. Always practise safer sex and use condoms.

Title: Treat shingles with Acyclovir now! [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SA002.|~|Background in green and black; text in white & black. Picture of a man with folded arms. He is asking: “Does your clinic have Acyclovir?”Additional image of human back with the caption "Herpes zoster" on it. The text: “Most government clinics do not provide Acyclovir. Lets campaign for it!” is surrounded by images of pills. Poster calls for campaign to get government clinics to provide the right treatment for their clients.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Shingles (Herpes zoster) causes:- painful blisters on a marked area on one side of the body.- possible blindness if it occurs in the face.- a scar that can burn badly.All this can be prevented if shingles is treated quickly with Acyclovir!Most government clinics do not provide Acyclovir. Let's campaign for it!|~|Additional poster text: Support voluntary HIV counseling and testing. There are direct benefits if you know your HIV status. There are medicines that improve your health. Always practise safer sex and use condoms.

Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Poster advocates for the aggressive use of Antiretroviral drugs (ARVs) to treat the 150,000 South Africans infected with AIDS by 2004.
Description.condition: "You can prevent HIV by using condoms & practicing safe sex at all times! If you test HIV positive and need treatment, Antiretrovirals (ARVs) can help. ARVs gave me back my health and took me back to my family and work." Vuyani Jacobs, one of 20,000 South Africans presently using ARVs.|~|For further informaiton on ARVs ask your doctor or contact TAC [Treatment Action Campaign] at: 021 788 3507; E-mail: info@tac.org.za; Website: www.tac.org.za|~|Selected additional poster text: ARVs are currently not available at public clinics and hospitals, we must campaign to change this. If you are on Medical AID or can afford ARVs, ask your doctor where you can buy them.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Relações sorodiscordantes [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BL003.|~|Poster depicts 6 circles outlined in red separated by male and female gender symbols. As a result three circles are to the right and three to the left of the gender symbols.  The circles have pictures of people. The first one of a family of four (mother, father, son and daughter). Next circle has a picture of a couple (man and woman). The third circle has a picture of a homosexual couple.  The fourth circle has a picture of a group of teenagers which includes two girls and two boys.  The fifth circle has a picture of a lesbian couple. Final circle depicts a couple (an elderly man and woman). The poster is about relationships in which one person is HIV positive and the other is negative.
AltTitle.translated: Serodiscordant relationships
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Saber lidar com as differenças é  um grande desafio.  Com a AIDS também é assim.  Para vencer esse desafio, os casais com sorologias diferentes para o HIV podem contar com aliados importantes, dentre eles, os profissionais de saúde.  Esses profissionais devem prestar orientações e ajudar no combate a discriminação.  Toda forma de amor seguro vale a pena!|~|Additional poster text:  ABIA 21 2223 1040 www.abiaids.org.br|~|Translated poster text:  Knowing how to deal with differences is a big challenge.  With AIDS it's the same.  To overcome that challenge couples with different serologies for HIV can count on important allies, amongst them, health professionals.  These professionals should provide guidance and help battle discrimination.  All forms of safe love are worthwhile.

Title: Bioseguridad [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CU007.|~|This poster discusses the importance of biosafety when it comes to health workers.  HIV can be transmitted if one is not careful to practice biosafety measures.  The poster shows pictures of medical workers wearing masks, gloved hands using hypodermic syringes and performing a dental exam, and a pair of hands being washed.
AltTitle.translated: Biosafety
Description.condition: Additional poster text: La frecuencia de exposición accidental de los trabajadores de la salud al VIH depende en gran medida de su actitud hacia la bioseguridad; Cumpla con las medidas de precaución universal e incorpórelas a su práctica diaria.|~|Translated poster text: The frequency of accidental exposure of health workers to HIV depends largely on their attitude towards biosafety; Comply with the universal precaution measures and incorporate them into your daily practices.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Só tens uma vida, usa o preservativo [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO017.|~|Poster depicts three images in three different squares. The top square has an image of a nude male body; another square with the words "joy stick" covers the male's genital area.  The second square depicts a female nude body with another square covering her genital area; that square has "play station" words in it. Third square has an image of what could be interpreted as a cell explosion. A square with "game over" covers the center of that image. On the very bottom of the poster there an image of an unwrapped condom. The poster depicts the male penis as being the joy stick and the women's vagina as bein the playstation and the game over being when both come into contact and no protection is used. Resulting in HIV infection.
AltTitle.translated: You only have one life, use a condom
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Joy stick. Playstation.  Game over.|~|Poster is part of "...porque a SIDA existe" [... because AIDS exits] campaign.

Description.condition: Número Verde: 800 225 115 email: abraco@mail.telepac.pt|~|Poster is part of "Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001" [World Campaign Against AIDS 2001].|~|Additional poster text: "Esta é uma causa justa." Ricardo Sá Fernandes, Advogado. ["This is a just cause." Ricardo Sá Fernandes, Lawyer.]|~|Poster is part of "...porque a SIDA existe: campaign.  Translated additional poster text: "...because AIDS exists"|~|Additional poster text: "10 anos de Abraço. 10 anos de luta. E mais 10 anos lutarei enquanto houver alguem que não se preocupe. Palavras de ordem: Amor, Mimo, Cumplicidade, Solidariedade, Esclarecimento, Qualidade, Relação, Abertura, Teimosia, Curiosidade, Saber, Cuidado, Ternura, Alegria, Coragem, Força, Persistência, Persitência, Persistência, Persistência, Persistência, Persistência, Persistência, Persistência, Persistência, Persistência..."  Margarida Martins Presidente de Direcção Executiva, Coordenadora do Programa ABC - Ser Criança, Apoio Social e Domiciliário, Marketing Relações Públicas. ["10 years of Abraço. 10 years of struggle. And 10 more years I will struggle as long as there's someone who doesn't care. Words of order: Love, Spoil, Complicity, Solidarity, Enlightenment, Quality, Relation, Openness, Stubbornness, Curiosity, Knowledge, Happiness, Courage, Will, Persistence, Persistence, Persistence, Persistence, Persistence, Persistence, Persistence, Persistence, Persistence, Persistence..." Margarida Martins Executive management president, Coordinator of ABC program - Being a child social home support, marketing and public relations.]

Name.creator: Martins, Margarida
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nós preocupamo-nos....e você?  [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Porque a SIDA existe!|~|Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO016.|~|Poster depicts three women standing on a stairs holding on to the rail. Two of the women are wearing jeans and another wearing a skirt.
AltTitle.translated: We worry about ourselves...and you?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: "Disse alguém que as mulheres carregam metade do céu. Se assim é, as mulheres seropositivas carregam o céu inteiro. Como mulher, sinto a obrigação de contribuir para a mudança da situação de milhões de mulheres que vivem com VIH/SIDA. Porque são sujeitas a uma dupla discriminação, mostram uma coragem do tamanho do universo."  Maria José Campos, médica, vice-presidente da Comissão Executiva Coordenadora da Rede Mediterrânica de Mulheres Confrontadas com a infecção peolo VIH. ["Someone says that women carry half of the sky, if that's the case then seropositive women carry the whole sky.  As a woman I feel the obligation to contribute to change in the situation of millions of women that live with HIV/AIDS.  Because they are subject to double discrimination, they demonstrate courage the size of the universe." Maria José Campos, doctor, vice-president of the executive commission, coordinator of the Mediterranean Network of Women Confronted by the HIV infection.]|~|Poster is part of "Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001" [World Campaign Against AIDS 2001].|~|Additional poster text: "SIDA não é sinónimo de morte, pode ser um convite à vida. É nosso dever não discriminar e abraçar quem precisa de nós." Helena Roseta, Arquitecta. ["AIDS is not a synonym for death, it can be an invitation to life.  It's our duty not to discriminate and give a hug to those who need us."  Helena Roseta, Architect.]|~|Número Verde: 800 225 115 email: abraco@mail.telepac.pt|~|Additional poster text: "A minha vida mudou porque eu tive a força para a mudar, mas foi a Abraço que me deu a mão para eu me levantar."  Ana Isabel Oliveira, Seropositiva / voluntáira. ["My life changed because I had the will to change it, but it was Abraço who gave me a hand to stand." Ana Isabel Oliveira, HIV positive / Volunteer]|~|Poster is part of "...porque a SIDA existe" [...because AIDS exists] campaign.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nós preocupamo-nos....e tu? [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Porque a SIDA existe!|~|Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO010b.|~|Poster depicts three people two men and a woman. The woman and a man are sitting down, the man is holding a soccer ball and another man stands behind them with his arms around them.
AltTitle.translated: We worry about ourselves...and you?
Description.condition: Poster is part of "...porque a SIDA existe: campaign.  Translated additional poster text: "...because AIDS exists"|~|Additional poster text: "O desafio que temos perante nós não é facil, mas não podemos perder tempo.  Temos que substituir a discriminação pela solidariedade. Temos que saber partilhar com aqueles que precisam de mais apoio. A SIDA é um problema de todos. Contem comigo."  Ricardo Sá Pinto Profissional de futebol. ["The challenge we have before us is not easy, but we cannot waste any time.  We have to substitute discrimination with solidarity. We have to know how to divide our support with those who need it the most. AIDS is everyone's problem. Count on me." Ricardo Sá Pinto Professional soccer player.]|~|Poster is part of "Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001" [World Campaign Against AIDS 2001].|~|Additional poster text: "Ajudar a tratar quem vive com esta infecção tem sido a minha batalha. Mas a querra só estará ganha quando cada um de nós se comprometer a não aumentar o número de infectados." Gabriela Rodrigues Médica, mãe de 4 filhos, voluntària do programa de prevenção da Abraço. ["To help care for those who live with this infection has been my battle.  But the war will not be won until each one of us compromises himself to not increase the number of infected." Gabriela Rodrigues, Dr., mother of 4, volunteer of the prevention program of Abraço.]|~|Número Verde: 800 225 115 email: abraco@mail.telepac.pt|~|Additional poster text: "Todos nós, jovens, devemos ter acesso à informação e a todos os meios de protecção da infecção pelo VIH (preservativos e material esterilizado de injecção). Devemos ser ouvidos e ter o direito de participar na construção dos programas de prevenção da transmissão da infecção pelo VIH." [All youth should have access to information and all means of protection against the HIV infection (condoms and sterilized materials for injections). We should be listened to and have the right to participate in the creation of prevention programs of transmission of the HIV infection.] Sérgio Luís Coordenador da região sul do programa de prevenção entre pares em meio escolar de Abraço

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nós preocupamo-nos....e você? [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001|~|Porque a SIDA existe!
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO012.|~|Poster depicts a man and a woman both dressed in suits sitting on chairs next to each other.The location is outdoors and you can see trees in the background.
AltTitle.translated: We worry about ourselves...and you?
Description.condition: Poster is part of "...porque a SIDA existe" [...because AIDS exists].|~|Additional poster text:  "Ao longo destes 10 anos de convivência diária com o VIH, aprendi a dar importância às pequenas coisas da vida, as quais, normalmente, nos passam ao lado...E a lutar pelo respeito à normalidade de que jamais devemos abdicar.  Não estamos cá para sobreviver - - vivemos.  Todos os dias!"  Miguel Rodrigues Pereira, Seropositivo, fundador de Abraço. ["For as long as these 10 years of daily coexistence with HIV, I've learned to give importance to the small things in life, which normally pass us by...And to fight for respect to normalcy which we should never abdicate.  We are not here to survive - - we live everyday! Miguel Rodrigues Pereira, HIV positive, Abraço founder.]|~|Número Verde: 800 225 115e-mail: abraco@mail.telepac.pt|~|Part of "Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001" [World Campaign Against AIDS 2001].|~|Additional poster text: "A SIDA é uma questão de todos, que exige uma resposta de todos.  Responde-se à SIDA com prevenção e responsabilidade.  Com solidariedade e urgência."  Maria José RittaPresidente da Commisão Nacional para o Ano Internacional dos Voluntários. ["AIDS is a question to everyone that requires and answer of everyone. Answer AIDS back with prevention and responsibility. With solidarity and urgency."  Maria Jose Ritta, President of the National Commission for the International Volunteers Year.]

Name.creator: Martins, Margarida
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Nós preocupamo-nos....e você?  [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001|~|Porque a SIDA existe!
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO013.|~|Poster depicts a man and women sitting at a restaurant having dessert.
AltTitle.translated: We worry about ourselves...and you?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: "A informação objetiva, isenta, não discriminatória e sem avaliações moralistas é um dos vectores essenciais da Prevenção, associada à disponibilidade e fácil acesso aos meios de prevenção e redução de riscos e a um ambiente social favorável." "Por isso nós informamos, editando, desde 1996, a única publicação periódica em português de e para as pessoas com VIH/SIDA."  Pedro Silvério Marques Seropositivo, sócio fundador, membro da Comissão Executiva e director do Boletim da Abraço. ["Objective information, exempts without discrimination and without moralist evaluations as one of the essential factors of prevention associated with the availability and easy access to means of prevention and risk reduction and to a socially favorable environment.  That's why we inform by publishing, since 1996 as the only periodical information in portuguese for people with HIV/AIDS."  Pedro Silvério Marques Seropositive, partner founder, member of the Executive Commission and director of Boletim da Abraço.]|~|Número Verde: 800 225 115 email: abraco@mail.telepac.pt|~|Poster is part of "...porque a SIDA existe" ["... because AIDS exists"] campaign.|~|Poster is part of "Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001" [World Campaign Against AIDS 2001].|~|Additional poster text: "Lembrar que a SIDA representa, em certos países um novo holocausto, é um dever de jornalista. Lembrar que é preciso lutar contra os preconceitos, é um imperativo da cidadã."  Maria Elisa Domingues Jornalista. ["To remind that AIDS represents in certain countries a new holocaust, is a journalist duty. To remind that it's necessary to fight against prejudice is imperative of the citizen."  Maria Elisa Domingues Journalist.]

Description.condition: Poster is part of "Campanha Mundial Contra a SIDA 2001" [World Campaign Against AIDS 2001].|~|Additional poster text: "Pode não ser ainda possível curar esta doença - SIDA -, mas é certamente possível, e dever de todos, preveni-la e denunciar sempre a solidão que a cerca." Teresa Salgueiro, Cantora. ["There might not yet be a cure for - AIDS - but it's certainly possible and everyone's duty to prevent it and always denounce the loneliness that comes with it."  Teresa Salgueiro, Singer]|~|Additional poster text: "Nas vossas mãos eu me alimento, nos vossos olhos eu adormeço, com o vosso abraço poderei voltar a sonhar."  Pedro Esteves Hemofilico/Seropositivo. ["In your hands I live on, in your eyes I fall asleep and with your hug I can dream again."  Pedro Esteves, Hemophiliac/HIV-positive.]|~|Poster is part of "...porque a SIDA existe" [...because AIDS exists] campaign.|~|Número Verde: 800 225 115 email: abraco@mail.telepac.pt|~|Additional poster text: "Cuidar dos outros, como gostariamos que cuidassem de nós ."  Carla Sezões Educadora Social do Programa da Abraco de Apoio Domiciliário Dr. José Luís Champalimaud (area metropolitana de Lisboa). ["To take care of others how we would like others to take care of us" Carla Sezoes Social educator of Abraco, home counseling Dr. Jose Luis Champalimaud (metropolitan area of Lisbon).]

Title: Syphilis. Lass dir nichts anhängen. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU060.|~|Part of a neck and hairy chest of a male who is wearing a green sweater.  He is wearing a gold necklace with a gold charm reading "Syphilis."|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Don't let anything be attached to you.
Description.condition: Additional text in German: “Ungeschützter sex Erhöht das Infektionsrisiko bei Syphilis. Eine Behandelbare Geschlechtskrankheit. Die unbehandelt zum Tod führen kann. Die Syphilis ist wieder da GEH ZUM TEST! Mehr infos unter www.syphilis.at. Eine initiative von Homed. Der verein Homed wurde im Jahr 2000 gegründet und widmet sich unter anderem der Gesundheitsprävention.”Text in English: “Unprotected sex increases the risk of infection with Syphilis. A treatable sexually transmitted disease which untreated can lead to death.  A Homed initiative. Homed Association was founded in the 2000 and is dedicated amongst other things to disease prevention.”

[Condoms protect not only from AIDS, but also from other sexually-transmitted diseases -- therefore: Condom? For sure!]|~|AIDS-Hilfe Wien|~|Graphic, comic book like caption, portraying two boys with an open condom on the table. One of the boys is looking and pointing his forefinger at the viewer. The other boy is standing behind the first boy and winking at the viewer and making a "thumb's up" gesture with his thumb. The round table is high above by the boys' faces. The yellow condom is being presented to the viewers with black color rays on top and the words JUST USE IT in English on the bottom. On the top of the poster beneath the words "Kondome? Na Sicher!" a radiation box (resembling long star) is present with a message in German. The poster seems to target adolescents.|~|Bottom left corner: Herausgeber: BM fur Arbeit, Gesundheit und Soziales, Stubenring 1, 1010 Wien, Sowie aids info AIDS-Hilfen, Bestelltelefon: (01) 711 00 DW 6140

Title: Steht immer richtig. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU056.|~|Austrian soccer star Markus Kiesenebner is shown bare-chested facing the viewer. He has a large tattoo of a dragon with presumably Chinese writing on his left arm. The head of the dragon is depicted on his shoulder and the tattoo stretches almost to his forearm.  On the bottom right of the poster two attached condoms, one has an inscription ASK FOR, askö  wien. The inscription is followed by a website www.askoe-wien.at (a sports related website). The other condom has the logo of AIDS HILFE which is a drawing of a outline of a house with the AIDS ribbon on it. The words AIDS HILFE appear on the bottom of the logo.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Always stands tall.

Title: Lässt nichts durch. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU057.|~|Austrian soccer star Helge Payer is shown bare-chested facing the viewer. He plays as a goal keeper, suggesting the importance of behaving defensively to keep the AIDS virus out of your body. He is looking straight at the onlookers and his hands are open in such a way that he is defending his goal.  There is a glowing light behind him, and his hands seem to be holding an invisible soccer ball. Two condoms, still in their packages, are shown on the bottom right of the poster; one has an inscription ASK FOR, askö wien. The inscription is followed by a website www.askoe-wien.at (a sports related website). The other condom has the logo of AIDS HILFE which is a drawing of a outline of a house with the AIDS ribbon on it. The words AIDS HILFE appear on the bottom of the logo.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Does not let anything through.
Description.condition: Additional text in German on the bottom right of the poster: "Profis haben's einfach drauf." Text in English: "Professionals are always prepared."

Title: What should a real Scotsman wear under his kilt?  A condom [incribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SC001.|~|The poster shows a male model posing for a portrait dressed in only a kilt.Under the title of the poster there is information for Scottish AIDS Moniter(SAM).  SAM porvides information and education on HIV and AIDS as well as direct services for people with HIV and AIDS.  The National Office is located at 64A Broughton Street, Edinburgh EH1 3SA and their phone number is: 031-557 3885.  The information for the Glasgow office is: 22 Woodside Terrace, Glasgow G3 7XH and their phone number is:  041-353 3133.
Description.condition: Additional poster text:  National AIDS helplines:  If you have any questions or want to talk to someone you can phone the National Aids Helpline, freephone 0800-567 123;       24 hours a day.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sichert gut ab. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item AU058.|~|Nina Burger, an Austrian soccer player, plays as a forward. She is standing barechested, her hands crossed to cover her breasts. She looks at the onlookers with the same determination when she tries to score a goal. She is being protective of her naked body. On the bottom right of the poster, two attached condoms, one has an inscription ASK FOR, askö  wien. The inscription is followed by a website www.askoe-wien.at (a sports related website). The other condom has the logo of AIDS HILFE which is a drawing of a outline of a house with the AIDS ribbon on it. The words AIDS HILFE appear on the bottom of the logo.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Protects well.
Description.condition: Additional text in German on the bottom right of the poster: "Profis haben's einfach drauf." Text in English: "Professionals are always prepared."|~|Austria. Bundesministerium für Bildung, Wissenschaft und Kultur

Title: Wereldwijd 13 miljoen aidswezen [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE037.|~|Three children are looking down into two graves, presumably those of their parents.|~|Translated additional poster text: Miriam has no father and no mother anymore, only a brother and a sister.  Millions of AIDS orphans must fend for themselves this way.  Stop AIDS Now! is working on care, prevention and a vaccine.  Stop AIDS Now! is an initiative of: Aids Fund, Hivos, ICCO, Memisa and Novib.  Support the fight against AIDS, www.StopAidsNow.nl or call 020 -5287828.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: There are 13 million AIDS orphans worldwide
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Miriam heeft geen vader en geen moeder meer, alleen een broer en een zus.  Miljoenen aidswezen moeten zichzelf zien redden.  Stop Aids Now! werkt aan zorg, preventie en een vaccin.  Stop Aids Now! is een initiatief van: Aids Fonds, Hivos, ICCO, Memisa en Novib.  Steun de strijd tegen aids, www.StopAidsNow.nl of bel 020 -5287828.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Take care, living positHiv [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE040.|~|Translated additional poster text: An action on World Aids Day 2001, for and by the gay community in Amsterdam.  Mon. Nov. 26-Fri. Nov. 30: COC: films on the theme of HIV/AIDS, acts and performances in gay clubs (Havana, SOHO, April, Exit, More, Trut).  Sat. Dec. 1: Westermarkt: unveiling giant red ribbon, presentation by the youth network Jongpositief.  Tues. Dec. 4: Schorerstichting: discussing "20 years of HIV in the scene - HIV change (ours)."  For program and information visit: www.hivnet.org or call the Aids Fonds, Raoul Fransen: 020-62 62 669.|~|One man stands behind another, with his arms around the front man.  Only their torsos are visible.  The man in front is wearing a t-shirt with "Take care, living positHiv" on it.  The poster is advertising a program of activities for HIV-positive gay men surrounding World Aids Day.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Een actieweek rond Wereld Aids Dag 2001, voor en door de gay-community in Amsterdam.  ma 26 t/m vr 30 november: COC: themafilms rond hiv/aids, acts & performances in de homo-horeca (Havana, SOHO, April, Exit, More, Trut).  za 1 december: Westermarkt: onthulling reuze Red Ribbon, presentatie jongerennetwerk Jongpositief.  di 4 december: Schorerstichting: debat "20 jaar hiv in de scene - hiv verandert (ons)."  Voor programma en informatie kijk op: www.hivnet.org of bel het Aids Fonds, Raoul Fransen: 020-62 62 669.

Title: Lang leve de liefde [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE038.|~|Translated additional poster text: Information and tips about love, dating, sex and safe sex. For all your questions, www.safesex.nl, on safe sex.  If you are in love. And then there's dating. How far do you want to go? I have safe sex, or I don't have sex at all. What you need to know about the condom and the pill. How do you manage (to have safe sex)?|~|A female and a male kiss deeply.  The photograph is highly pixellated, as if it were blown up from a magazine.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Long live love

En dan is er verkering.  Hoe ver wil je gaan?  Ik vrij veilig, of ik vrij niet.  Wat je moet weten over het condoom en de pil.  Hoe speel je het klaar (om veilig te vrijen)?

Name.sponsor: United States. HIV/AIDS Treatment Information Service
Title: Check this out! [inscribed]
Description.note: Pink poster with picture of a smiling African American woman.  Poster suggests that HIV positive pregnant women can transmit their virus to the fetus.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: If you have HIV and are pregnant you could pass the virus to your baby.  Talk to a health care provider or call the HIV/AIDS Treatment Information Service at 1-800-448-0440 or 1-800-243-7012 (TTY service for the deaf) for information on HIV

Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Dept. of Health and Human Services
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: You can't get HIV here... [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Business responds to AIDS; Labor responds to AIDS.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US057.|~|Poster depicts a common things found in the work place such as a drinking fountain, a urinal handle, a computer keyboard, and a telephone receiver.  Poster suggests that although you cannot get HIV from any of the things pictured, you can get HIV info at the workplace.|~|Part of "Business responds to AIDS; Labor responds to AIDS" campaign.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: or here...; But you can get HIV/AIDS info in this workplace; HIV hasn't gone away.  Neither have the concerns it raises--like worker morale, discrimination and productivity.  Get free workplace policy and education information.  Check www.hivatwork.org, or call 1-800-458-5231.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Black baby and white baby [descriptive]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE048.|~|Translated poster text: Why didn't he get them?  And he did?  Everyone has the right to AIDS inhibitors.  Giro 8957.  Aids Fonds.  As long as the AIDS virus is active, we will be, too.|~|Two naked babies sit side by side, one black and one white, with their backs facing us.  The poster implies that the black baby did not get HIV drugs, but the white baby did, and that Aids Fonds is trying to make the drugs available to all.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Waarom hij niet?  En hij wel?  Iedereen heeft recht op aidsremmers.  Giro 8957.  Aids Fonds.  Zolang het aidsvirus actief is, zijn wij dat ook.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV@Work [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Business responds to AIDS; Labor responds to AIDS.
Description.note: Part of "Business responds to AIDS; Labor responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster shows a picture of a male construction worker with arms folded and a stern expression.  Poster suggests that the number of people employed and with HIV is climbing.  There is information available for people with HIV and the workplace.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Does the job right; Can-do attitude; Always thinking; Earns respect; Living with HIV; More people are living and working with HIV than ever before; HIV hasn't gone away; Neither have the concerns it raises--like worker morale, discrimination and productivity; Add HIV/AIDS to health and wellness programs and workplace policies.  Everyone benefits.  After all, investing in people is an investment in the future; Get free workplace policy and education information.  Check www.hivatwork.org, or call 1-800-4548-5231; HIV is still in business.

Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE044.|~|Two girls are sitting on a bed in a messy teenage bedroom.  One girl (via a conversation bubble) is saying that she never thought she would get an STD from him.  The other girl has her arm around her, and she is thinking (via a thought bubble), how could anyone have sex without a condom?|~|Translated poster text: ... I never thought that I could get an STD from him ... Then who can screw without a condom?  www.safesex.nl.  AIDS and STD hotline: 0900-204 2040 (€ 0.10/min.)|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: ... nooit gedacht dat ik een soa van hém zou oplopen ... wie laat zich dan ook naaien zonder condoom.  www.safesex.nl.  Aids Soa infolijn: 0900-204 2040 (€ 0,10 p/min)
