Publisher.publisherName: STOP AIDS Århus|~|STOP AIDS (Denmark)|~|STOP AIDS København
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Faste forhold og løse forbindelser [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK004.|~|Translated additional poster text: “One time hook-ups and loose partners. No thanks, that’s not really me, given the way things are. I keep myself to one at a time.” (Ole, 41). “Condoms give a kind of freedom, I think. If, for example, I do something ‘wrong’ one day, then I don’t have to tell my lover/sweetheart just before we’re going to have sex. I can wait until I want to. And without having a bad conscience because of that. So, in one way, I think you can say that condoms give me a kind of ‘spiritual’ freedom." (Svend, 34).|~|Multicolored blurred images of naked male couples embracing and kissing. Quotes from "Ole" and "Svend" talk about different kinds of sexual behavior in an environment where HIV infection is a risk.
AltTitle.translated: Stable relationships and loose connections
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Grafisk design: Peter Waldorph på foto af Knud Vesterskov.|~|Additional poster text: “Engangsknald og løse partnere? Nej tak, det er ikke lige mig, som tiderne er. Jeg holder mig til en ad gangen.” (Ole, 41) “Kondomer giver en slags frihed, synes jeg. Hvis jeg f.eks. en dag sku’ lave noget ‘forkert,’ sa behøver jeg ikke sige det til min kæreste, lige før vi skal bolle. Det kan jeg vente med, til jeg har lyst. Og uden at få dårlig samvittighed af den grund. Så på en måde synes jeg godt, man kan sige, at kondomer giver mig en slags ‘åndelig’ frihed.” (Svend, 34). Stop AIDS København tlf: 33112911. Stop AIDS Århus tlf: 86128800.

Title: Most people think HIV is only a problem in big cities.  Unfortunately, I was one of those people. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US043.|~|This poster features a message from Krista Blake: a Caucasian female infected with HIV, walking along a country road.  She urges viewers to learn more about HIV because it happens to everyone, regardless of where they live or their economic status.  She wants viewers to not make the same mistake she did.|~|Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: One in 250 Americans is infected with HIV. 1-800-342-AIDS.

Title: HIV@Work [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US056.|~|Part of "Business responds to AIDS; Labor responds to AIDS".|~|Poster shows a photo of a road worker, fireman, construction worker, and a cleaning lady with solemn expressions looking at the audience.  Poster suggests that blue collar everyday people are living and working with HIV.  There is information available to prevent the disease from adversely affecting the workplace.|~|Part of "American responds to AIDS campaign".
Description.condition: Additional poster text: More people are living and working with HIV than ever; HIV hasn't gone away.  Neither have the concerns it raises--like worker morale, discrimination and productivity.  Get free workplace policy and educaiton information.  Check www.hivatwork.org, or call 1-800-458-5231.; HIV is still in business.

Title: Als er niemand meer is die voor haar zorgt, zorgen wij voor haar [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Unite for children, unite against AIDS
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Joanina, 11 years old, Mozambique.|~|A close-up photograph of an African girl, identified as 11-year-old Joanina from Mozambique.  She is presumed to have been orphaned by AIDS.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: If there is no one else there for her, we will care for her
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Word daarom nu lid op unicef.nl.  Joaninha, 11 jaar, Mozambique.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Saunafyre har altid HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK017.|~|Organization web site: http://www.farligeformodninger.dk|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|A man with a pierced ear and a tattoo on one arm, naked except for a white towel around his waist. His face is shiny and his hair is damp, as though he has just come out of a sauna. A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether gay men who frequent bathhouses are more likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Sauna guys always have HIV -- or what?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Farlige formodninger? De fleste mænd bruger kondom og glidecreme, når de har sex med en ny partner. Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.|~|Text in bottom left corner of poster: Design: Mikkel Sonne; Foto: Morten Wøldike; Tryk: Eks-Skolens Treykkeri APS.

Title: Infezione da virus dell'AIDS? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT009.|~|The background of the black-and-white poster consists of 25 thumbnail images, each of which is a drawing of an individual person talking into a telephone. There are 8 different drawings, some of which are repeated. They depict one woman and several men; their clothing is characteristic of their status: professional worker, blue-colar worker, student. The drawings illustrate that people from all genders and walks of life can call this health network and speak anonymously with a physician about their AIDS-related health issues, and receive free medical advice and testing. In the center of the poster is a large letter C on a blue background.  The telephone number, the Stop AIDS slogan, and the Gruppo C name are lettered in red. All other lettering is in white over a black background.|~|Translated poster text: Stop AIDS. We worry about your health, not your identity. Anonymous, a doctor on the telephone, free testing.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Stop AIDS. Ci preoccupiamo della tua salute, non della tua identità. Esami in anonimato, un medico al telefono, analisi gratuite.

Title: Dalla solidarietà la prevenzione [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT013.|~|The text on this poster appears on an illustration that resembles a mirror-image Rorschach ink-blot design, with the top half mirrored on the bottom (which is upside-down).  The design suggests a group of people, and is colored with a watercolor wash of orange, green and brown shades. The top group of people is divided from the upside-down bottom group, illustrating the message that if fear divides us, AIDS will grow. At the bottom of the poster appears a logo: two telephone receivers with a red drop of blood in between them.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Se la paura ci divide, l'AIDS cresce.  Progetto di ricerca AIDS 1990 - Ministero della sanità Istituto superiore di sanità; ULSS 25 Verona, Regione Veneto; 045-30843 Gruppo C. "Project 045/6300214" is inscribed along the right hand edge of the poster.|~|Translated poster text: From solidarity comes prevention.  If fear divides us, AIDS continues to grow.

In the background are a full moon and a serpent, symbols of the night and passion and temptation. Underneath the drawing are the words, "La Prudenza" or Prudence. The woman draws the viewer to her, but indicates that it is necessary to take prudent measures and have safe sex. Part of a "Stop AIDS" campaign.

Name.sponsor: Global Coalition on Women and AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Description.note: Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: No sex.  No home.    That's the choice I face.  I know this can make me vulnerable to HIV.  But if I want a home and my family secure, it is hard to say no to my husband's demands.  This has to change.     Equality for women helps fight AIDS.

Publisher.publisherName: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|~|Global Coalition on Women and AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA011.|~|Poster depicts a woman from the waist up, leaning against a wall and wearing a striped t-shirt and a scarf. She is smiling at the viewer. The space over her head and below her waist is in shadow. Although women account for half of the people infected with HIV or AIDS, poster implies that they often don't have a voice. Promoting equal rights for women will help in the fight against AIDS.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: In small print on bottom left of poster: The text on this poster does not necessarily represent the situation, opinions, views or beliefs of the person depicted.|~|Additional text: I am a mother, daughter, sister, partner, friend. I run a home. I work, feed my family, bring up my children. I keep us smiling. I am HIV positive and I live in your community. To keep doing all this, I need your support and respect. Equality for women helps fight AIDS.|~|www.worldaidscampaign.org; womenandaids.org; www.unaids.org

Title: Be free [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT010.|~|The poster depicts a drawing of a blue, old-fashioned dial telephone, on a blue background which incorporates the words, "solo sesso sicuro." Into the design of the phone dial are integrated the signs for male and female; the holes in the dial show the numbers for the hotline telephone number.  The theme of this poster is that safe sex prevents the risk of AIDS, and that more information about AIDS as well as free, anonymous HIV testing are available by calling Gruppo C's hotline number.|~|Translated additional poster text: AIDS information, anonymous HIV testing. Unprotected sexual relations are a risk to your health.  Call Grouppo C of the Centro de Medicina Preventiva.  Safe sex only.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Subject.conceptTopic: Women--Health and welfare|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|Women's rights
Name.sponsor: Global Coalition on Women and AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign
Publisher.publisherName: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS
Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA015.|~|Photograph of a woman, probably of South Asian descent, looking towards but not directly at the viewer.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: No respect.  No hope.  Many of us do not command enough rights or respect in our communities.  We are more likely to face sexual violence and can't find jobs or own property so easily.  This makes us more vulnerable to HIV.  This has to change.  Equality for women helps fight AIDS.

Name.sponsor: Italy. Ministero della sanità|~|Gruppo C, Network Italiano
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Test HIV [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT012.|~|Underneath the title, "Test HIV," is a large black arrow pointing downwards to words which translated reads, "Getting the test is important for you and for others."Along the left side of the poster in white lettering on a blue background is a textual explanation of how AIDS is transmitted (sharing needles, from sexual relations, from an infected mother to her baby). Also explained is the need to take a simple blood test, and advice about how it is voluntary and anonymous to do so; the results are confidential. Finally there is the warning that many people have contact with HIV without knowing it.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Fare il test e'importante per te e per gli altri. Stop AIDS, Progetto del Ministero della Sanità, ex Secedas. In collaborazione con Gruppo C Network Italiano.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: N'oublie pas le secret de Valery [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE011.|~|Poster depicts the face of a girl, Valery, in one large square panel bordered on its left edge by three smaller square panels showing Valery in different scenes: the top panel shows her with classmates; the middle one shows her holding a flip board presentation on AIDS and STD's; and the bottom one shows her being embraced by a younger girl. A fourth circular panel in the upper right corner of the main panel shows an urban landscape, most likely Valery's hometown. The poster serves as an advertisement for Meteor, an educational kit that teaches children about other children affected by AIDS.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Translated additional poster text: Health, everyone's right! Meteor is a tool for fostering humane values, aimed at children 10 to 12 years old. By hearing stories from children their age, students become aware of other realities and other ways of life. Meteor consists of a film, a booklet, and teaching manual.
AltTitle.translated: Don't forget Valery's secret
Description.condition: Additional text: La santé, un droit pour tous! Meteor est un outil d'éveil aux valeurs humanitaires destiné aux enfants de 10 à 12 ans. En découvrant l'histoire vraie d'un enfant de leur âge, les écoliers prennent consciences d'autres réalités et d'autres modes de vie. Meteor se compose d'un film, d'une brochure et d'un dossier pédagogique.

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Stereotyping|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Aktive fyre har aldrig HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK013.|~|Organization web site: http://www.farligeformodninger.dk|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|A young man in a green t-shirt and black jeans stands with one hand hitched in his pants pocket. A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether gay men who are dominant (i.e. "tops") in sexual situations are less likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Active guys never have HIV -- or what?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Farlige formodninger? De fleste mænd bruger kondom og glidecreme, når de har sex med en ny partner. Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.|~|Text in bottom left corner of poster: Design: Mikkel Sonne; Foto: Morten Wøldike; Tryk: Eks-Skolens Treykkeri APS

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Stereotyping|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Villige fyre har altid HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK012.|~|A shirtless young man in jeans and a baseball cap stands pointing at his buttocks. A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether sexually promiscuous gay men are more likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|Organization web site: http://www.farligeformodninger.dk|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Willing guys always have HIV – or what?
Description.condition: Text in bottom left corner of poster: Design: Mikkel Sonne; Foto: Queerstock; Tryk: Eks-Skolens Treykkeri APS.|~|Additional poster text: Farlige formodninger? De fleste mænd bruger kondom og glidecreme, når de har sex med en ny partner. Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.

Title: Unge fyre har aldrig HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]

AltTitle.translated: Young guys never have HIV -- or what?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Farlige formodninger? De fleste mænd bruger kondom og glidecreme, når de har sex med en ny partner. Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.

Description.condition: Selected poster "headlines:" NU kan det fortælles; Snusk & snag; Jeg var et svin!; Veninde i dyb rædsel: Ført bag lyset.

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Stereotyping|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Passive fyre har altid HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK014.|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|A male with his back turned is pulling down his jeans to reveal his buttocks. A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether gay men who play a more submissive role (i.e. "bottoms") in sexual situations are more likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Passive guys always have HIV -- or what?
Description.condition: Text in bottom left corner of poster: Design: Mikkel Sonne; Foto: Morten Wøldike; Tryk: Eks-Skolens Treykkeri APS.|~|Additional poster text: Farlige formodninger? De fleste mænd bruger kondom og glidecreme, når de har sex med en ny partner. Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.|~|Additional poster text: http://www.farligeformodninger.dk

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Grande simulatrice [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE012.|~|Translated additional poster text: Sexually transmitted diseases are not always visible. Track them down.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Poster depicts an unmade bed. Two pillows are partially shown: one is black and the other is black-and-white, with a pattern of circles encompassing radially-oriented swirls, reminiscent of the motion that induces hypnosis. A similarly patterned comforter is pulled back to reveal a white satin sheet with thin folds arranged in the shape of the word: Syphilis. The phrase "La Grande Simulatrice" is inscribed underneath in a red dot-matrix, suggestive of bullet holes.  Possibly encourages the user to have the stealth of a skilled hunter to track down and eliminate undetectable STDS--by practicing safe sex.
AltTitle.translated: Grand illusionist
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Les IST* ne sont pas toujours visibles. Faites un dépistage.*Infections sexuellement transmissible

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Karrierefyre har aldrig HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK016.|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|Organization web site: http://www.farligeformodninger.dk|~|A young man with a shaved head wearing a green polo shirt and standing with his arms crossed. A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether career-oriented me, or "yuppies," are less likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Career guys never have HIV -- or what?
Description.condition: Text in bottom left corner of poster: Design: Mikkel Sonne; Foto: Morten Wøldike; Tryk: Eks-Skolens Treykkeri APS.|~|Additional poster text: Farlige formodninger? De fleste mænd bruger kondom og glidecreme, når de har sex med en ny partner. Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.

Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|World AIDS Day|~|Prejudice|~|AIDS phobia
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: People's faces and their prejudices toward people with HIV and AIDS [descriptive]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE010.|~|Translated additional poster text: "Stay away from my sister."  "What will our family say about that?"  "You deserve it."  "Stay out of our neighborhood."  "You can't be in our class."  "We should not play with you."  "Wonderful résumé, but are you HIV positive?"  "Go somewhere else to sleep."  "It is your own fault."  These are just some of the most painful consequences of HIV and AIDS.  Help us fight fear, shame, prejudice and injustice worldwide.  Get involved, check www.sensoa.be.  December 1.  World Aids Day.  Give to AIDS.  096-555- 55 55-95.  Based on a campaign of UNAIDS.|~|Nine disapproving faces of men, women, and children, accompanied by the judgemental and prejudical things about HIV and AIDS they are saying or thinking.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: "Blijf van mijn zuster."  "Wat gaat onze familie daar van zeggen?"  "Je verdient het."  "Blijf uit onze buurt."  "Je kan er niet bij in onze klas."  "Wij mogen niet met jou spelen."  "Prachtig cv, maar ben je seropositief?"  "Ga ergens anders slapen."  "He is je eigen schuld."  Dit zijn maar enkele van de meest pijnlijke gevolgen van HIV en AIDS.  Help ons mee te vechten tegen angst, schaamte, vooroordelen en onrechtvaardigheid, wereldwijd.  Doe mee, check www.sensoa.be.  1 december.  Wereldaidsdag.  Geef om AIDS.  096-555- 55 55-95.  Gebaseerd op een campagne van UNAIDS.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Oraal, vaginaal, anaal.  En verbaal? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE013.|~|A nude man and a woman appear to be having sexual intercourse on a couch.  There are black bars over their mouths, signifying that they are censoring themselves.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Translated additional poster text: Talk about what you feel good about right away. What you expected, your borders. And ask the same of your partner. Because good communication means good sex.  Sensoa.  Talk about sex.
AltTitle.translated: Oral, vaginal, anal.  And verbal?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Zeg beter meteen waar je je goed bij voelt.  Wat je verwacht, waar je grenzen liggen.  En vraag van je partner hetzelfde.  Want goeie afspraken maken goeie seks.  Sensoa.  Praat over seks.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Je tong verloren tijdens het kussen?  [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE015.|~|A male and a female lie naked together, posed to be near kissing.  There are black bars over their mouths, signifying that they are censoring themselves.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Translated additional poster text: Just because you're attracted to each other doesnot mean that you can read each other's thoughts. So be bold enough to say and ask what you feel good about, what you expect from one another, and where your boundaries lie.  Because good communication means good sex.  Sensoa.  Talk about sex.
AltTitle.translated: Lost your tongue during the kissing?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Verliefd zijn op elkaar wil nog niet zeggen dat je elkaars gedachten kunt lezen.  Durf dus allebei te zeggen en te vragen waar je je goed bij voelt, wat je van elkaar verwacht en waar je grenzen liggen.  Want goede afspraken maken goede seks.Sensoa.  Praat over seks.

Title: Pijpen: gebruik je hoofd [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE042a.|~|Translated additional poster text: 1. When you give a blowjob, you can easily get an STD.  2. There is also a small risk of HIV.  3. Wounds in the mouth increase the risks.  4. If you have an STD, you are more likely to get HIV.  Read more about it in the folder!  AIDS and STD hotline: 078 15.15.15, www.sensoa.be.|~|A black and white closeup of a man's nose and mouth.  The poster text explains that it's possible to get HIV through oral sex, and very easy to contract an STD.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: To give a blowjob: use your head
Description.condition: Additional poster text: 1. Bij pijpen loop je makkelijk een soa op.  2. Er is ook een klein risico op HIV.  3. Wondjes in de mond verhogen de risico's.  4. Heb je een soa, dan loop je makkelijker hiv op.  Lees er meer over in de folder!  AIDS en soatelefoon 078 15.15.15, www.sensoa.be.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: On pense que-- on croit que-- mais les suppositions ne nous protègent pas [inscribed].
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE028.|~|According to the publisher's website, viewed Jan. 31, 2008, the theme of this poster was the theme of a 1999 campaign.|~|Poster depicts two gay men dressed in orange and black clothing, standing apart and with their backs to each other, one looking over his shoulder at the other. The image is blurred,suggesting that they are not seeing each other clearly. Two quotations adjacent to the images indicate what each man is thinking, revealing that each has made false assumptions about the other.
AltTitle.translated: We think that-- We believe that-- but assumptions don't protect us.
Description.condition: First quotation adjacent to images: "Je suis séropositif, j'ai pensé qu'il l'était aussi. Il n'a pas proposé le préservatif."["I'm HIV positive, I thought that he was also. He didn't offer a condom."]|~|Second quotation adjacent to images: "Je pense que je suis séronégatif. Je présume qu'il l'est aussi puisqu'il n'utilize pas de préservatif. Si il avait le sida, il le dirait." ["I think I'm HIV negative. I assume that he is also since he doesn't use a condom. If he had AIDS, he would say so."]|~|Text at bottom of poster: Nous tenons à remercier The Terrence Higgins Trust et la Communauté française pour leur précieux soutien. Coordination: Thierry Martin. Ed. resp.: François Delor.|~|Additional text at bottom of poster: Pour obtenir notre brochure ... www.exaequo.be

Title: On pense que-- on croit que-- mais les suppositions ne nous protègent pas [inscribed].
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE030.|~|According to the publisher's website, viewed Jan. 31, 2008, the theme of this poster was the theme of a 1999 campaign.|~|Poster depicts two gay men, one dressed in an orange shirt and black trousers, the other in an open blue shirt and black trousers, standing apart and with their backs to each other. The image is blurred, possibly suggesting a lack of clear understanding or perception. A quotation above the image indicates that one man has made a potentially false assumption about the other and has engaged in unsafe sex.
AltTitle.translated: We think that-- we believe that-- but assumptions don't protect us.
Description.condition: Additional text at bottom of poster: Pour obtenir notre brochure ... www.exaequo.be|~|Text at bottom of poster: Nous tenons à remercier The Terrence Higgins Trust et la Communauté française pour leur précieux soutien. Coordination: Thierry Martin. Ed. resp.: François Delor.|~|Quotation above the image: "Hier, je n'ai pas mis de préservatif. Il m'a fait perdre la tête. Mais il n'était sûrement pas contaminé, il était jeune et paraissait vraiment en bonne santé." [Yesterday, I didn't use a condom. He made me lose my head. But he was definitely not infected, he was young and seemed really healthy.]

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW215.|~|Different sizes and colors of pills standing against a variegated blue background. Poster suggests that condom use is easier than a lifetime of taking pills to manage HIV.
AltTitle.translated: HIV pills. Swallowing them is no party
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Die Deutsche-AIDS Hilfe E.V.: Lebenslange Einnahme kann zu schweren Nebenwirkungen führen! Kondome schützen vor HIV und mindern der Risiko einer Ansteckung mit anderen sexuell übertragbaren Krankheiten! [Taking for a lifetime causes severe side effects! Condoms protect from HIV and reduce the risk of other sexually transmitted diseases!]

Subject.conceptTopic: HIV Infections--therapy|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Es gibt Dinge... die darf man nicht vergessen [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW246.|~|Part of the "Gib AIDS keine chance" campaign.  Image of a Dalmatian chained to a lightpost in the middle of a desert and sand dunes with the sand tinted red.|~|Poster number GW177 has the same image but different text.
AltTitle.translated: There are things one should never forget
Description.condition: "AIDS ist ein großes, weltweit zunehmendes Problem. Es bleibt eine tödliche Krankheit, für die es in absehbarer Zukunft keine Schutzimpfung oder Heilung gibt. Medikamente können des Ausbruch von Aids nach einer HIV-Ansteckung nur verzögern." (AIDS is a large, world-wide increasing problem. It remains a fatal illness does not remain, for in the forseeable future there is no vaccinaton or cure. Medicines can only delay the onset of AIDS after an HIV infection)

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Si tout ce que vous savez de moi est que j'ai le VIH, vous ne me connaissez pas du tout [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Semaine canadienne de sensibilisation au VIH/sida 2002
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN036_2.|~|A seated man wearing a white dress shirt with collar open and sleeves rolled up gazes openly and directly at the viewer. Indistinctly seen behind him is what appears to be a blackboard, possibly indicating that he is a white-collar worker. He is neither old nor young, and neither his ethnicity nor his occupation is apparent, hence he represents Everyman.
AltTitle.translated: If all you know about me is that I have HIV, then you don't know anything about me
Description.condition: La Semaine canadienne de sensibilisation au VIH/sida 2002, 24 novembre au 1er décembre 2002.|~|Additional poster text: Chaque année, le VIH infecte encore des milliers de Canadiens. Le VIH/sida n'a pas de préférence.|~|Les vues exprimées ici ne représente pas nécessairement la position officielle de Santé Canada.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: How could someone like me be HIV positive? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN045_1.|~|Young man in his teens or early twenties, of mixed race, looking at the viewer and smiling.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Average student.  Likes to have a good time.  Wishes he could talk to his older brother more often.  Spaghetti and meatballs is his favourite meal.  Wants to learn to play euchre.  Has seen every episode of "Star Treck: Next Generation" at least twice.  Wants to become a teacher.  Gets angry when he hears people say that HIV/AIDS isn't a big deal anymore.  Canadian HIV/AIDS Awareness Week 2002- November 24-December 1, 2002

Obtenez les faits et informez-vous sur les facons d’arrêter la transmission du VIH et la discrimination.|~|Cette campagne est coordonnée par le Centre canadien d’information sur le VIH/sida, un programme de l’Association canadienne de santé publique. La production du présent document a été rendue possible grâce à une contribution financière de Santé Canada. Les vues exprimées ici ne représentent pas nécessairement la position officielle de Santé Canada.
Relation.hasVersion: Because of HIV, Sara's friends don't talk to her anymore. Don't add to her isolation [English]

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV. It doesn't discriminate. Do You? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN053.|~|Poster  has large "HIV" in handwriting style typeface at top, and line below is in smaller regular print "It doesn't discriminate" and main body of text with phone number is below.  In the lower left hand corner is a symbol wih a butterfly, above a lower case "act" followed by a stylized backwards "c", and the words AIDS Committe of Thunder Bay.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: We give our care and support to people who get cancer from smoking. Why should we blame people who have become infected with HIV? People with HIV/AIDS deserve the same acceptance and understanding as anyone else with a life threatening illness.  Concerned? Trade fears for facts. Call for a free borchure. 1-807-345-2526.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: I am the changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN054.|~|In lower left hand corner of poster is a stylized logo, with a butterfly and "act" in lower case letters, with a reverse "c" after "act".  In a black border at the bottom of the poster are the words "AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay."|~|Additional poster text:  I am 46. I am divorced and sexually active. I am a social drinker. I've had a number of partners and sometimes I forget to use a condom when I have sex. Not only that, I like to experiment with some sex partners. So, I worry about getting AIDS. I wish I had someone to talk to about this.  You do. Call (807)345-1516 or 1 800 488-5840 today.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Description.condition: Additional poster text: N’importe quand. N’importe où. N’importe qui. Le VIH/sida n’a pas de préférence. La semaine canadienne de sensibilisation au VIH/sida 2002 - 24 novembre au 1er décembre 2002. [No matter when. No matter where. No matter who. HIV/AIDS has no preference. Canadian HIV/AIDS Awareness Week, 24 November to 1. December 2002]|~|Additional poster text: Chaque année, le VIH infecte encore des milliers de Canadiens. Et nos attitudes affectent leur vie tous les jours.[Thousands of Canadians are still being infected with HIV every year. And they’re being affected by our attitudes every day.]

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Are you negative about positives? [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Reality check : many of us are living with HIV. We're part of the community. We work and play together. We have sex.

Title: Il aime ça sans capote. Il doit être séropositif [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN071.|~|Other people involved in poster creation: Raúl Cabra, Andy Williams, Wesley Ito, Liz Craig and Jillian Moffett.|~|This poster depicts a grainy black and white photograph of a young white man with his head and chest visible, lying face-up on his back with his head on a pillow.  His eyes are shut and his brow is furrowed, lips are slightly open, suggesting that he is in the act of intercourse.  The text of the poster suggests the importance of not making assumptions, and of knowing about the other person’s HIV status to prevent contracting it.|~|Based on the San Francisco "Assumptions" campaign, the slogan reads, "Comment fais-tu pour savoir?" English version is: "How do you know what you know?" www.penses-y.ca|~|Poster is copyright 2004 Cabra Diseño and San Francisco AIDS Foundation. www.cabradiseno.com
AltTitle.translated: He does it raw. He must be positive.

English version is: "How do you know what you know?" www.penses-y.ca|~|Poster is copyright 2004 Cabra Diseño and San Francisco AIDS Foundation. www.cabradiseno.com|~|A poster with two black-and-white photos placed side-by side, showing the upper bodies of two men, one behind the other, both facing to the left of the scene.  The man on the left is light complected, with short dark hair, mustache and beard, and his eyes are closed.  The second man is posed behind the first; he has dark skin and his eyes are also closed. The positions suggest that they have just had anal intercourse. Each man is making an assumption about the other and whether each is HIV-positive or negative. Poster text suggests the importance of being informed about HIV to prevent contracting it.|~|Other people involved in poster creation: Raúl Cabra, Andy Williams, Wesley Ito, Liz Craig and Jillian Moffett.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: True leaders. HIV AIDS the healing begins with us. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN024_1.|~|Against a background of rolling green hills and a river, native Canadians are depicted interacting with each other. In the foreground, an older woman is shown cooking for a group surrounding her. To her left is a young man wearing graduation robes and holding a feather. Behind them, two women are talking; one is holding a clipboard and wearing an AIDS ribbon. To the right, a young boy is being handed a bowl by a kneeling older man. The poster suggests that native people can and should take a leadership role in prevention the spread of HIV/AIDS and providing support for those already infected.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: In the bottom of the poster there is a red ribbon and this note in both languages English and French: Aboriginal AIDS Awareness Day, December 1. Journee de Sensibilisation des Autochtones sur le Sida, 01 Decembre.Also there is the website of CAAN which is:www.caan.ca
Description.caption: Les vrais chefs. VIH SIDA la guerison commence avec nous.

One man is playing a fiddle while another looks on, and there are music notes next to them. Another man (wearing an AIDS ribbon) is adjusting the neckerchief of a man in traditional native American dress. There is a mother (perhaps an Inuit woman, suggested by her clothing) with a child on her back. Finally, there are a man and woman holding hands. The healing begins with us.December 1, Aboriginal AIDS Awareness Day.|~|Additional poster text: L'espoire d'une cure. L'espoire qu'ensemble -- le VIH/SIDA peut être surmonté. L'espoire d'un avenir meilleur en vivant mieux aujourd'hui. L'espoir de communautés plus coopératives. L'espoire que notre peuple réussira encore une fois. La foi dans les forces traditionnelles de notre peuple. VIH/SIDA. La guérison commence avec nous. 01 decembre, Journée de sensibilisation des autochtones sur le SIDA.

Title: Bravo. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR084.|~|This poster is depicting a young girl with a long blond hair who is looking compassionately to the onlookers, as she is saying don’t worry you are not alone.  The inscription “Bravo, vous faites désormais partie des gens qui n'ont pas peur d'approcher une personne séropositive.” (Congratulations, you are here as part of a group of people who are not afraid to approach a person who has tested HIV positive,) is on the mouth of this young girl.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: Congratulations.

Description.condition: AIDS loves a good party. A few drinks and every-one lets down their guard. Party smart. Keep one guard on duty. Use a condom.|~|For information call: 345-1516. ACT: A message from the AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: We talk [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK053.|~|Additional poster text: --We talked about everything. I hoped that meant we'd never have to talk about whether one of us might have HIV. It's taken time, but we're talking again. That's a start. But I wish we had talked about it before.|~|In white border at bottom of poster:  "For more information."  A logo in red for GlaxoSmithKline Positive Action at Work. And a second logo for NAT with a red ribbon National AIDS Trust.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Thank you. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK054.|~|The poster is a thank you note that expresses the feelings of the people who are getting the word out to people in the workplaces.  The word "Thank" is in light blue; the word "you" is in yellow.  The background of the poster is in a light red.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text:  We want to say "Thank you" to all our HIV and AIDS Peer Educators.  Without them we wouldn't have been able to bring our employees all the information and workplace activities that help us fight HIV discrimination, prevent infections and promote testing, care and treatment.  It's not an easy job, but if you would like to join them, they still need more help.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Changez le monde [inscribed]
AltTitle.other: Defendez les droits humains.|~|Ensemble nous pouvons faire une différence.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN085_2.|~|Part of "Change the world" campaign.
Description.condition: Additional poster text:La discrimination liée au vih empêche les gens d'obtenir l'information et le soutien dont ils ont besoin. www.campaign.CPHA.ca. Le vih ne fait pas de discrimination.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN015.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|The poster doesn't have any picture, it only includes the word AIDS in big and in vertical way. On the letter A of AIDS it is written "The changing face of". Under the word AIDS there are 4 columns in each one there is a small text.
Description.condition: For information call: 1-807-345-1516. ACT: AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay.|~|Additional poster text: BIGOT? HIV/AIDS does not discriminate between straight, gay, young, old, or the colour of one's skin. It sees us all equally- as potential targets. Get the facts. Risk? HIV/AIDS is a risk- especially if you drink before sex or use intravenous drugs. AIDS can be prevented. Learn how to protect yourself. GET IT? don't HIV/AIDS is final. And it's occuring more in women, our young people and aboriginal population. Find out what you can do about it. GOT IT? Living with HIV/AIDS isn't easy. Fear is terrible thing to face alone. If you or someone you know is infected, help is available. Give us a call.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Discriminación, si no te sube la presión, hazte un chequeo. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA008.|~|The web site for the Pan American Health Organization appears on the blood pressure machine: http://www.paho.org/|~|Poster depicts a blood pressure machine at the center of the poster and the word "discriminacion" (discrimination) all across the poster.
AltTitle.translated: Discrimination, if your reaction is slow, get a checkup.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: "Todo paciente tiene derecho a la mejor atencion de salud disponible, independientemente de su condicion de salud, raza, edad, orientacion sexual o nivel socioeconomico."|~|Additional poster text: "La discriminacion es un problema que afecta a toda la sociedad. En los servicios de salud, personas con VIH y otras enfermedades a menudo sufren discriminacion. Por eso, chequee los siguientes sintomas de discriminacion:  Rechazo a ingresar a pacientes con VIH/SIDA en un establecimiento de salud, retrasar la atencion del paciente, demora o negacion de otras formas de atencion como higiene o alimentacion, alta prematura de pacientes, realizacion de pruebas medicas sin consentimiento del paciente, violacion de la confidencialidad dentro o fuera del sistema de salud, comentarios impropios como el uso de ironias o juicios fuera de lugar, excesivas medidas de precaucion al asistirlos.  Trabajadores de la salud: aliados en la lucha contra la discriminacion.|~|Translated additional poster text:  "Every patient has the right to the best available health care, regardless of your health condition, race, age, sexual orientation or socioeconomic status."|~|Translated additional poster text: Discrimination is a problem that affects all society. Within the health services, people with HIV and other diseases are sometimes affected by discrimination. Check for these symptoms of discrimination: Refusal to admit patients to health care facility, delay treatment, other forms of care (e.g. food hygiene) delay or withheld, premature discharge of patients, testing with consent, breach of confidentiality within or outside the health care system, inappropriate comments or behavior (e.g. shouting, rudeness), use of excessive precautions. [Health workers: partners in the fight against discrimination]

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Вы меня услышали сегодня? [inscribed]
Description.note: Photograph of a woman, probably of South Asian descent, looking towards but not directly at the viewer.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA016.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Нет уважения-нет надежды. Многие из нас не имеют достаточных прав и уважения в своей общине. Мы чаще подвергаемся сексуальному насилию и нам труднее найти работу или владеть собственностью. Это делает нас более уязвимыми к ВИЧ. Это надо менять. Равенство для женщин помогает бороться со СПИДом. [Net uvazhenii︠a︡-net nadezhdy. Mnogie iz nas ne imei︠u︡t dostatochnykh prav i uvazhenii︠a︡ v svoeĭ obshchine. My chashche podvergaemsi︠a︡ seksualʹnomu nasilii︠u︡ i nam trudnee naĭti rabotu ili vladetʹ sobstvennostʹi︠u︡. Ėto delaet nas bolee ui︠a︡zvimymi k VICh. Ėto nado meni︠a︡tʹ. Ravenstvo dli︠a︡ zhenshchin pomogaet borotʹsi︠a︡ so SPIDom].

Title: Sexually transmitted infections [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK033.|~|Poster depicts image of stethoscope with a condom in place of a diaphragm.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: There are many different STIs-and some you would not know you have without a check up. Using condoms protects against many common STIs as well as unwanted pregnancies and HIV. Leaving an STIs untreated can turn a simple problem into a serious one, and may leave you more vulnerable to HIV infection. Have a check up, for the sake of your sexual health.

Title: Discrimination, if your reaction is slow, get a checkup [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA007.|~|The web site for the Pan American Helth Organization appears on the handle of the reflex hammer:  http://www.paho.org/|~|At the top of the poster the word discrimination is printed in large letters.  Within the black outlined letters you can see the ocean shoreline in orange, grey, purple and light green.  Under the word discrimination, there is a reflex hammer with several red ribbons attached to the side of the head of the hammer.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text:  Every patient has the right to the best available health care, regardless of health condition, race, age, sexual orientation or socioeconomic status.|~|Additional poster text:  Discrimination is a problem that affects all society.  Within the health services, people with HIV and other diseases are sometimes affected by discrimination.  Check for these symptoms of discrimination: Refusal to admit patients to health care facility, delay treatment, other forms of care (e.g. food hygiene) delay or withheld, premature discharge of patients, testing with consent, breach of confidentiality within or outside the health care system, inappropriate comments or behavior (e.g. shouting, rudeness), use of excessive precautions. [Health workers:  partners in the fight against discrimination]

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV and AIDS: the facts [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK031.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: HIV is the virus that causes AIDS. It attacks the human immune system, leaving an infected person vulnerable to a number of serious illnesses and cancers. The virus lives in the blood, vaginal fluid and semen of infected people. But the virus does not survive for long in the open air and can only be passed on by certain kinds of direct contact.HIV is contracted through vaginal or anal sex without a condom, injection or injury with used needles, mother to unborn or newborn baby. HIV is not contracted through working with people with HIV or AIDS, coughs and sneezes, holding hands, insect bites, food or knives and forks, toilets or sinks, protected sex with proper use of a condom.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Not until you're diagnosed HIV positive do you discover how sick people can get. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK040.|~|Poster depicts HIV case study list, and is in black and white.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Hate mail. Abusive phone calls. Even aggressive confrontations and physical attacks. This is how some people who are HIV positive are treated. And not just by strangers. By work colleagues, by former friends and sometimes even by close family. And it's not unheard of either for people with HIV to be discriminated against by health workers. Yet the fact is, there's no reason for them to be treated differently from anyone else. You can't contract HIV by working or socialising with someone who has it. And thanks to new treatments, its possible for people with HIV to lead full and active lives. All that's stopping them is other people's ignorance. Are you HIV prejudiced? To learn the facts, go to www.areyouhivprejudiced.org. By ending ignorance, we'll end prejudice.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Do you have time? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK036.|~|Poster depicts image of stopwatch.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: five people worldwide die of AIDS every minute. Take a minute: 1st December is World AIDS Day. For confidential information and advice on safer sex, HIV and AIDS call 0800 567 123 anytime.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Could you look me in the eye if you knew that I had HIV? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK038.|~|Poster depicts black and white photograph of man’s face. The question: “Could you look me in the eye if you knew that I had HIV?” is written in his eyes.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: A lot of people couldn't. Some even go out of their way to avoid you. Even friends and members of your own family. Can you imagine how that feels? The isolation and the loneliness? Yet the fact is you can't contract HIV from working or socialising with someone who has is. And thanks to new treatments, most people with HIV can now lead full active lives. All that's stopping them is other people's ignorance. Are you HIV prejudiced? By ending ignorance, we'll end prejudice.

Title: Pour que l'espoir vous succède-- la solidarité en héritage [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR134.|~|Translation of additional poster text: To give to charity is to give hope to people we will never know. As an "Association Reconnue d'Utilité Publique", AIDES may receive donations and bequests exempt from inheritance taxes. The entirety of bequests can therefore be devoted to the fight against AIDS.|~|Poster consists of a drawing of an older man, wearing glasses, seated on a park bench with his arm around a child; the older man is pointing at the sky in which scattered stars and stars formed in the shapes of two hearts are present. Both the older man and the child are smiling and looking at the hearts in the sky.|~|Possibly part of a 2003-2004? campaign to encourage bequests and gifts to the Aides organization.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: So that hope will live on-- show you care by leaving something to charity
Description.condition: Text on right-hand side of poster: AIDES 0404-- Maquette: S. Blot -- Illustration: PIEM extraite de "Petits enfants, Grands parents", edité par le Cherche midi.|~|Additional poster text: Léguer un bien ou faire un donation, c'est transmettre de l'espoir aux personnes touchées au-delà de sa propre vie. En tant qu'Association Reconnue d'Utilité Publique, AIDES peut recevoir des donations et des legs exonérés de tous droits de succession. L'integralité des biens légués est donc consacrée à la lutte contre le sida.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Homme averti....[inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR088.|~|This poster is a collection of colored drawings in a comic book style. These pictures tell a story of a gay man who is looking for love. It resembles a situation comedy, for instance, the hero is watching TV and getting information on different subjects. The story is building up to a conviction that he could have unsafe sex, because in the news he is hearing that scientists have some drugs that improve the immune systems of people with AIDS. When he meets with his partner he ridicules him for trying to use condom; he declares "haven’t you seen the news on TV?" When he learns that his partner does not have TV, he tells him you are so uniformed, how do you get through life?|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
AltTitle.translated: An Informed man...
Description.condition: Additional text in the bottom right of the poster in French: “ Pour en parler Sida Info Service: 0800 840 800 (24h/24 anonyme, confidential et grantuit)”Text English: “To talk about it call AIDS Info Service: 0800 840 800 (24h/24 anonymous, confidential and free)”

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Hoe het condoom gebruiken? [inscribed]
Description.note: Illustrated instructions of how to effectively use and dispose of a condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE048.
AltTitle.translated: How do you use a condom?
Description.condition: Additional poster text: For a hundred million reasons ... 1. Scheur de verpakking aan de inkeping open zonder het condoom te beschadigen. Neem het condoom er voorzichtig uit.2. Knijp het reservoire (topje) van het condoom dicht tussen duim en wijsvinger. Zo vermijd je dat er lucht in blijft.3. Plaats het condoom tegen de top van de stijve penis en rol het met de andere hand volledig af.4. Trek na het klaarkomen terug als de penis nog stijf is, terwijl je het condoom vasthoudt.5. Gooi het gebruikte condoom weg in de vuilnisemmer.Sensoa: Praat over seks.Voor persoonlijke vragen over HIV, soa en anticonceptie kan je terecht bij veilig vrijenlijn (078-15 15 15). Meer infor over HIV, soa anticonceptie op www.sensoa.be.|~|Translated poster text: 1. Tear open the package at the notch without damaging the condom. Remove the condom carefully. 2. Squeeze the reservoir (tip) of the condom between your thumb and forefinger. Make sure no air remains. 3. Place the condom against the tip of the erect penis and roll it on completely with the other hand. 4. Pull back after ejaculation while the penis is still stiff, holding the condom. 5. Throw away the used condom in the garbage. Sensoa: Talk about sex. For personal questions about HIV, STDs, and contraception, you can contact the safe sex line (078-15 15 15). More information on HIV, STDs, and contraception at www.sensoa.be.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Lucas ou le secret de l'invisibilité. [inscribed]
Description.note: Translated additional poster text: ...Lucas has won his place among the great minds of the the 21st century, despite being unscientific he managed to discover the secret of invisibility without knowledge of experimentation or complicated calculous, all he had to do was announce he was HIV postive to his family. He noted the effectiveness of his discovery. It was more or less immediate. People's looks changed, the calls stopped. That was it -- he was invisible. Certainly Lucas was a true genius. Still he would have preferred to have discovered a treatment to prevent AIDS.The best treatment is our support.Aids the great national cause|~|The picture shows a man opening both his hands, palms up. He is wearing a jacket and pants. Next to the man's picture there is a small article.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR139.
AltTitle.translated: Lucas, or the secret of invisibility.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: Gráce á sa découverte révolutionnaire. Lucas s'est imposé en très peu de temps comme un des plus grands gènies du XXIe siècle, pourtant Lucas n'a rien d'un sceintifique mais voila il a découvert le secret de l'invisibilité sans même faire d'expériences ou de calculs compliqués, non du jour ou il a annonce sa seropositivité a son entourage. Il a constaté l'efficacité de sa découverte. L'effet est plus ou moins repide. Les regards changent, les coups de fil s'arrétent. Puis ça y est -- il est devenu transparent. C'est sur Lucas est un genie un vrai. Mais bon il aurait tout de meme préféré trouver un traitement contre le Sida.Le premier traitement, c'est notre solidarite.and"SIDA Grande Cause Nationale 2005"

Description.condition: Translated poster text: European photography competition 2007. Affected by AIDS and HIV? Fight stigma and discrimination associated with this disease by participating in the photography competition on "alternative look". Send your photos that show how a person living with AIDS sees the negative and vice versa ... Deadline to submit your photos: March 15, 2007. Bristol-Myers Squibb is committed to the fight against AIDS and sponsors the annual photography contest "One Vision" to fight against stigma and discrimination that patients face. 4 European prizes (total: 14 000 €) and numerous national awards (1 000 € each). For more information on the competition and send your photos, visit: www.onevision2007.org|~|Additional poster text: concours europeen de photographie 2007. Concerné par le sida et le VIH? Combattez la stigmatisation et la discrimination liées à cette maladie en participant au concours de photographie sur le thème "regards alternatifs". Envoyez vos photos qui montrent comment une personne vivant avec le sida voit les séronégatifs et vice versa... Date limite pour déposer vos photos : 15 mars 2007. Bristol-Myers Squibb est engagé dans la lutte contre le sida et parraine chaque année le concours de photographie "One Vision" pour lutter contre la stigmatisation et la discrimination auxquelles les patients sont confrontés. 4 prix européens (montant total : 14 000 €) et de nombreux prix nationaux (1 000 € chacun). Pour plus d'informations sur le concours et pour envoyer vos photos, consultez le site: www.onevision2007.org

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sida ne fait pas que des morts. Il fait aussi des orphelins. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster shows four cartoon silhouttes of people, three are adults and one is a child. All of them have targets on their chests, however the adults have bullhole like spots around their targets and one of them is missing his head and shoulders.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR163.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS does not just kill. It also orphans.
Description.condition: Translated poster text: In 2001, over 13 milion children have lost one or both parents to AIDS ... in 2010, it will be 26 million. Why is it important to take action? These children are exposed daily to malnutrition, deprivation of their property, lack of education, alcoholism, crime ... Left to themselves, they are the target of numerous acts of violence: economic exploitation of their labor, abuse ... Orphans are becoming the main victims of sexual assault and in some countries they are the first enlisted in armed conflict. AIDS orphans are a particularly fragile generation due to being exposed to an early HIV infection. Help us help them.To sponsor an orphan or send donations, contact AIDS Orphans International|~|Additional poster text: En 2001, plus de 13 milions d'enfants ont perdu un ou leurs deux parents des suites du sida... en 2010, ils seront 26 millions. Pourquoi il est important d'agir? Ces enfants sont quotidiennement exposés à des risques vitaux intolérables : malnutrition, privation de leurs biens, déscolarisation, alcoolisme, délinquance... Livrés à eux-mêmes, ils sont la cible de nombreuses exactions : exploitation économique de leur force de travail, maltraitance... Les orphelins deviennent de fait les premières victimes des agressions sexuelles et dans certains pays en guerre, les premiers enrôlés dans les conflits armés. Les orphelins du sida ont une génération particulièrement fragilisée et exposée, à son tour,à une contamination précoce par le vih. Aidez-nous à les aider.Pour parrainer un orphelin ou envoyer vos dons, contactez Orphelins Sida International, 47/49 rue des maraîchers 7502 Paris - France - 01 47 97 54 94

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Je n'oublierai jamais le jour de mon proces. [inscribed]
Description.note: Color mural on the side of a wall of the face and shoulders of a sad looking boy with miniature hands pointing at him.    To the right of the boy is the text of a narrative of the boy's experience revealing the fact that he is HIV positive.  To the right of the text is a separate part of the wall with a statistical fact about HIV positive people and family rejection.  Poster alludes to the social aspects people face as far as being discriminated against, feared, and denied affection when diagnosed with HIV.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR195.
AltTitle.translated: I will never forget the day of my trial.
Description.condition: Additional poster text: 1 séropositif sur 3 est rejeté par sa propre famille.  Stop à l'exclusion.  Quand je suis passé aux aveux ily a eu un long silence gêné dans l'assemblée pour la premiére fois de ma vie, j'ai sentir quel point sa pouvait faire mal d'être juge-onm'a accusé...|~|Translated additional poster text: 1 out of 3 HIV positive people are rejected by their family.  Stop the exclusion.  When I confessed a while ago there was a long awkward silence in the assembly for the first time in my life, it hurt to be accused...

Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--psychology|~|HIV infections--Social aspects
Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Jack est formidable. [inscribed]
Description.note: Color mural on the side of a wall of a man holding and using a can of spray paint.  The emission from the spray can is forming the phrase "Jack est formidable".  Below the emission is text of the narrative of the man's experience revealing to a loved one that he is HIV positive.  Below the narrative is text of a statistical fact about HIV positive people and loneliness.  Around the man are images depicting dogs including dog heads with the bodies of humans.  There is also a dog looking at the mural from the sidewalk.  Poster alludes to the social aspects people face as far as being discriminated against, feared, and denied affection when diagnosed with HIV.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR196.
AltTitle.translated: Jack is great.
Description.condition: Translated additional poster text: It was perfect the day I told him that I was HIV positive... 7 out of 10 HIV positive people suffer from loneliness.  Stop the exclusion.|~|Additional poster text:  Il a été parfait le jour oû je lui ai annoncé  que j'etais séropositif. 7 séropositifs sur 10 souffrent de solitude. Stop A L'exclusion.

Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: J'ai toujours reve d'etre une actrice. [inscribed]
Description.note: Color mural on the side of a wall of a woman sitting with her arms folded.  To the right of the woman is an image of a flyer for a play which describes how the woman cannot pursue her dreams of becoming an actress because she constantly has to hide the fact that she is HIV positive.  In between the woman and the flyer there is text of a statistical fact about how people conceal the fact that they are HIV positive.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR197.
AltTitle.translated: I always dreamed of being an actress.
Description.condition: Translated additional poster text: Stop the exclusion. 2 out of 3 HIV positive people conceal their HIV status for fear of discrimination. I waited, and then one day it happened without me. I played a student funny and carefree...|~|Additional poster text: Stop à l'exclusion. 2 séropositifs sur 3 dissimulent leur séropositivité par peur discriminations.   Et puis un jour c'est arrivé sans que je ne m'y attende. J'ai joue une étudiante drole et insouciante.

Below the cartoon is a list of AIDS prevention related events going on during the week including a brief description and where they are.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Title: Sida, en parler pour mieux lutter [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster advertising the World Day To Combat AIDS on December 1, 2007.  Poster has a cartoon of a man picking up a woman to go on a date.  On the stairwell is the woman's parents reminding her to not forget to use a condom.  To the left and right of the cartoon are HIV statistics in relation to France.  Below the cartoon explains that HIV positive people can be employed in almost every job without risk to themselves or others.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR199.
AltTitle.translated: AIDS, talk to fight better
Description.condition: Additional poster text: 1er décembre 2007 - journée mondiale de lutte contre le sida.  La quasi-totalité des postes de travail peut être tenue par des salariés atteints du VIH sans risque pour leur santé ou celle de leurs collègues.  Tu n'as rien oublié ma chérie.|~|Translated Additional poster text: December 1st 2007 - World Day to Combat against AIDS. Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ne banalisons pas le sida! [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster for World Aids Day on December 1st 2006.  Poster has a cartoon of two boys with a box of condoms.  The boy on the left is chewing one of the condoms mistaking it for chewing gum.  The boy on the left is reading the box and saying that the gum is "lubricated".  To the left and right of the cartoon are facts and statistics about HIV and AIDS.  The poster's overall message is that AIDS is not funny and ironically depicts a humorous cartoon about condoms.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR200.
AltTitle.translated: Do not trivialize AIDS!
Description.condition: Translated additional poster text: December 1st 2006 - World Day to Combat against AIDS. Hey, what is with your yucky chewing gum! It has what? It is' lubricated. It's full of vitamins to stop AIDS.|~|Additional poster text: 1er décembre 2006 - Journée mondiale de lutte contre le sida.  Dis donc, ils sont dégueu tes chewing gums! C'est a quoi?  C'est au 'lubrifié.  C'est plein de vitamines pour pô attraper le sida.
